cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant has raised three specific technical objections regarding bonus calculations: income-tax computation, return on working capital, and depreciation reserve treatment. The judgment excerpt explicitly states that the tribunal's treatment of depreciation reserve 'is clearly incorrect in view of this Court's decision in The Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd.' This indicates at least one ground where the appellant's challenge has merit based on established Supreme Court precedent. The income-tax calculation also appears to have mathematical errors (Rs. 1.67 lacs vs. Rs. 2.25 lacs). These technical errors in the tribunal's calculations strongly suggest the appeal will be at least partially allowed for recalculation.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's argument that 'no appeal shall lie' creates an absolute bar until tax payment appears legally sound under the proviso to Section 30(1). The cited precedents (Raja of Venkatagiri and Kamdar Brothers) support the interpretation that the right to appeal itself is conditional upon tax payment, not merely the remedy. While the respondent filed the appeal before the limitation period expired, the tax was paid only on May 16, 1955, after both the due date and the appeal filing date, suggesting the appeal was premature and incomplete when filed. The statutory scheme appears to require tax payment as a precondition to a valid appeal, making the memorandum filed without payment ineffective.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Tribunal's interpretation that Section 30(2) bars only the remedy but not the right of appeal appears legally sound. The respondent paid the tax before the appeal was heard, and the penalty was imposed for a technical default. The distinction between a procedural bar and substantive right typically favors allowing appeals where the underlying tax liability has been satisfied, even if belatedly.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts establish legal necessity for all four items totaling Rs. 1,600, which lower courts confirmed and even Misra J did not dispute. The central legal issue is whether a widow can sell (rather than mortgage) property subject to usufructuary mortgage when necessity exists. The prudent owner test supports the sale as a reasonable means to redeem part of the mortgage and restore income-generating capacity to the estate. While respondents challenge bona fides, the structured use of sale proceeds for documented necessities (debt redemption, agricultural equipment, repairs) demonstrates legitimate purpose. The widow's broad powers of alienation when necessity is established, combined with undisputed factual findings on necessity, strongly favor upholding the sale as binding on reversioners.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court acknowledged that all four items of consideration were supported by necessity (a factual finding binding in second appeal), yet rejected the sale based on a conflicting precedent regarding a widow's power to sell mortgaged property. The Supreme Court granted leave specifically noting the conflict between two Patna High Court decisions and the importance of settling both the substantive legal issue and the practice regarding conflicting precedents. Given that necessity was established and the High Court's decision rested on choosing between conflicting authorities rather than on the merits, there is a strong likelihood the Supreme Court will resolve the conflict in favor of upholding sales supported by genuine necessity, thereby accepting the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's constitutional challenges face significant obstacles. Article 31(5)(b)(iii) explicitly protects evacuee property laws from Article 31(2)'s compensation requirement, and the Court appears to have upheld this protection extends to laws empowering authorities to declare evacuee property, not just laws directly declaring it. The Custodian made a factual finding that the evacuee did not act in good faith—a well-established legal standard—which provides sufficient grounds for rejection under Section 40(4)(a). The discrimination claim is weak since the Custodian's order is judicial in nature, and alleged errors in other cases do not constitute discrimination under Article 14. The precedent in Rabia Bai supports the Custodian's authority to refuse confirmation based on bad faith.
cases.raw_reasoning: The petitioner challenges the constitutionality of the Evacuee Property Act, arguing it violates Article 31(2) by taking property without compensation. However, Article 31(5)(b)(iii) explicitly exempts laws dealing with evacuee property from Article 31(2)'s compensation requirement. The petitioner's narrow interpretation that this exemption applies only to laws directly declaring property as evacuee (not laws empowering authorities to do so) is unlikely to succeed, as it would render the statutory framework unworkable. The petitioner exhausted all statutory remedies (appeal and revision) unsuccessfully, and the constitutional challenge faces a clear textual barrier in Article 31(5)(b)(iii).

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner challenges Madras court's jurisdiction to try a conspiracy offence committed in Calcutta. However, the cited precedent Purushottamdas Dalmia establishes that a court with jurisdiction over offences committed in pursuance of conspiracy can also try the conspiracy itself, even if committed elsewhere. Since the substantive offences (cheating, forgery) were committed in Madras jurisdiction, and Section 239 CrPC is not controlled by Section 177 CrPC's territorial limitations, the legal framework supports the Madras court's jurisdiction. The petitioner's jurisdictional argument appears weak against established precedent allowing such trials.
cases.raw_reasoning: This appeal involves jurisdictional issues regarding criminal conspiracy under Section 120-B IPC read with Section 420 and forgery charges. The case appears to challenge the Madras High Court's order when the conspiracy allegedly occurred in Calcutta, raising significant questions about territorial jurisdiction. Such jurisdictional challenges often succeed when there are genuine disputes about the proper forum, and the Supreme Court typically intervenes to clarify jurisdictional principles in criminal matters involving multi-state offenses.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's constitutional challenge under Article 14 faces significant obstacles. The court materials indicate that persons transferring assets before and after October 18, 1949 are not similarly circumstanced due to different political contexts, satisfying the reasonable classification test. The statutory language of s.22(b) explicitly covers transfers made before declaration as an intending evacuee, and the High Court has already affirmed this interpretation. The petitioner's textual arguments appear weak against the plain meaning of the provision, and the discrimination claim fails because the two groups (pre- and post-October 1949 transferors) form distinct classes with rational nexus to the legislative policy.
cases.raw_reasoning: The petitioner challenges Section 22(b) on Article 14 grounds, arguing discrimination between intending evacuees and evacuees who performed similar acts. However, the classification appears reasonable as it distinguishes between those who transferred assets before vs. after October 18, 1949, a critical legislative cut-off date. The High Court upheld the declaration of evacuee property based on substantial asset transfers during the specified period, and the legislative scheme appears to have a rational nexus with the objective of preventing asset flight. The discrimination argument lacks sufficient merit to invalidate the statutory provision.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court's own finding that 'legal heirs took property subject to a trust rather than a charge' and that 'High Court conclusion is correct' strongly indicates the appeal will be rejected. The legal framework establishes that charitable purposes create fiduciary obligations on property owners, and precedents (Wybrants, Bailey v. Ekins) support that charges for charitable purposes can create trusts. The petitioners' argument that only a charge was created fails against the court's determination of a trust with fiduciary obligations for charitable purposes.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court has already ruled that a trust was created in favor of the Sabha, though limiting it to half share. The appellants challenge this finding, arguing only a charge was created. However, the legal principles cited distinguish trust from charge based on whether fiduciary obligations attach to the property itself. Given that both lower courts found a trust existed and the Official Trustees Act permits appointment where property is subject to trust, the appellants face a high burden to overturn concurrent findings on will construction. The Supreme Court typically defers to lower courts' interpretation of testamentary documents unless clearly erroneous.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner challenges jurisdiction and limitation issues, but the doctrine of protective/precautionary assessment is well-established in Indian tax law when income ownership is uncertain between assessees. The respondent's argument that such assessments prevent tax evasion when it's unclear which of two brothers received income has strong legal foundation. The jurisdictional challenges regarding the validity of orders under sections 5(2) and 5(5) appear technical, while the substantive issue favors allowing protective assessment to proceed against both parties until ownership is determined.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant challenges the jurisdiction of the Income-tax Officer based on an allegedly invalid transfer order by the Central Board. However, the court notes that even the respondent does not defend the validity of the original transfer order dated September 30, 1953. Since that transfer was invalid, the subsequent assignment to the Bombay officer was also invalid, meaning the case properly reverted to the original Jamnagar officer (first respondent) who has jurisdiction under section 64. The limitation issue is deemed premature for writ proceedings and should be raised before the Income-tax Officer. The jurisdictional challenge fails because the proper officer is now handling the case.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal framework strongly supports a broad interpretation of 'telegraph line' to include wireless receiving apparatus. The respondent's arguments align with established precedents (Attorney-General v Edison Telephone, King v Brislan) that modern statutes should be interpreted to encompass technological developments not existing at enactment. The petitioner's narrow textual argument contradicts the purposive approach courts take with modern legislation, and the High Court's invocation of contemporanea expositio for a 1910 statute appears erroneous. The factual finding of actual interference with wireless communications, combined with the inclusive statutory definition in Section 3(4) of the Telegraph Act, provides strong grounds for upholding the Inspector's jurisdiction under Section 34(2)(b).
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether 'telegraph line' under the 1885 Telegraph Act encompasses wireless telegraphy equipment. The Act defines 'telegraph line' as 'a wire or wires used for the purpose of a telegraph' with associated apparatus. The appellants argue for a broad interpretation to include wireless equipment, but the statutory language explicitly requires 'wire or wires.' Since wireless telegraphy did not exist in 1885 and the definition is textually tied to physical wires, the High Court's strict construction appears legally sound. The principle of contemporanea expositio supports interpreting the statute according to its original meaning, making the Senior Electric Inspector's order likely ultra vires.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court's own holding that a member incurring disqualification under s.13-D(g) does not cease to be a member or lose the right to act until suspended or removed under s.40 is decisive. This means Ram Nath and Kesho Ram Gupta remained valid members capable of signing the notice and voting, making the no-confidence motion procedurally valid with 9 signatories out of 17 total members (more than half). The petitioner's core argument that disqualified members automatically lose their rights fails under this interpretation, and the High Court's validation of the motion appears legally sound.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appeal challenges a no-confidence motion against the Municipal Board President on grounds that signatories Ram Nath and Kesho Ram Gupta were disqualified members due to tax arrears under s.13-D(g). The High Court held disqualified members merely lose the right to 'act' but remain members. However, the Supreme Court excerpt indicates disagreement with this interpretation, stating 'We do not agree with the second contention for the appellant, or with the view expressed by the learned Judges.' This suggests the Court may find that disqualified members cannot validly participate in proceedings, potentially invalidating the no-confidence motion if their participation was essential to meeting the statutory threshold. The technical legal question about whether disqualification removes membership entirely versus merely suspending rights appears likely to be resolved in appellant's favor.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts explicitly state that the court holds the government's contention as 'well founded and order valid' under s.59, and finds 'no discrimination as all municipalities stand on same footing regarding milk.' The legal framework clearly establishes that s.59 makes tax imposition subject to government orders 'at any time,' even after sanction. The petitioner's arguments about timing restrictions and discrimination are directly contradicted by the court's factual findings and the plain language of s.59 allowing ongoing government control over tax imposition.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether the Government can withdraw sanction for an octroi tax after initially approving it under Section 59 of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901. The statutory language 'subject to any general or special orders the State Government may make in this behalf' appears to grant continuing supervisory power to the Government over tax imposition, not merely at the rule-making stage. The plain reading suggests the Government retains authority to issue orders affecting tax levy even after initial sanction, making the April 4, 1955 order legally valid. The Municipality's argument that Government power is exhausted after sanctioning the rule appears inconsistent with the ongoing subjection clause in Section 59.

cases.graph_reasoning: The payment structure based on per-ton cement manufactured and sold suggests a revenue receipt tied to ongoing commercial operations rather than a capital receipt from asset sale. The restrictions and retained rights in the deed indicate this was not a complete sale but a profit-sharing arrangement. The precedent in State of Bihar v Sir Kameshwar Singh supports treating such periodic payments as taxable income, which aligns with the Tribunal's finding that this was a revenue receipt.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant company was incorporated with the business object of acquiring and dealing with mining rights and concessions. The transfer of these rights to Associated Cement Ltd. and the receipt of payments based on cement production appears to be in the ordinary course of the company's business activities as authorized by its Memorandum of Association. The Tribunal's finding that the appellant was carrying on business for which it was incorporated, combined with the recurring nature of payments tied to production volumes, strongly suggests this is revenue receipt rather than capital receipt, making it assessable income.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's contractual tenancy expired by efflux of time in 1947, converting him to a statutory tenant under the West Bengal Premises Rent Control Act 1950. Section 12 protects statutory tenants from eviction except on specified grounds. The respondents established reasonable requirement for rebuilding, which is a valid ground under the Act. The acceptance of rent by landlords under rent control legislation does not create a new contractual tenancy requiring notice under Section 106 TPA, as established by precedent in Kai Khushroo. The appellant's protection is statutory, not contractual, and the landlords have met the statutory exception for eviction.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court reversed the Special Bench and restored the trial court's decree for eviction. The key issue is whether acceptance of rent after contractual tenancy expiry creates a statutory tenancy under s.116 of the Transfer of Property Act. The landlords' acceptance of rent appears involuntary due to rent control legislation protecting the tenant, not voluntary assent to create a new tenancy. The premises were reasonably required for rebuilding, satisfying grounds for eviction under the 1950 Act. The legal position favors landlords when rent acceptance is compelled by protective legislation rather than voluntary agreement.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether Section 87-B CPC, requiring Central Government consent to sue ex-Rulers, applies retrospectively to this pending suit and whether it violates Article 14. The legal framework strongly supports retrospective application—the word 'sued' in Section 86(1) read with 87-B includes continuation of pending suits, as established by cited precedents on retrospectivity. The doctrine of reasonable classification under Article 14's twin test appears satisfied: ex-Rulers form a distinct class based on historical integration covenants and Article 362's recognition of their privileges, with rational relation to the legislative object of honoring those commitments. Since the appellant admittedly failed to obtain required consent from the Central Government, the suit is procedurally incompetent regardless of merits. The agent liability argument under Section 230 Indian Contract Act appears weak given that consent is still required to sue the principal (ex-Ruler), making sub-section (3) inapplicable.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant challenges Section 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure as violating Article 14's equality clause and argues it cannot apply retrospectively to pending suits. However, Article 362 of the Constitution explicitly requires due regard to guarantees given to Indian Rulers regarding their personal rights, privileges and dignities. The exemption from civil jurisdiction without Central Government consent was a longstanding privilege recognized in covenants with ex-Rulers, and the constitutional protection under Article 362 provides a reasonable classification justifying differential treatment. The refusal of Central Government consent and the constitutional backing for such privileges strongly suggest the appeal will be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant has two independent grounds for eviction: (1) bona fide need under s.13(1)(e), and (2) tenant acquiring suitable alternative residence under s.13(1)(h). The trial court already decreed ejectment under s.13(1)(h), finding the respondent built a house in Golf Link Area. Even if the professional use complicates the s.13(1)(e) claim, s.13(1)(h) operates independently and does not require the premises to be purely residential. The respondent's arguments about who built the Golf Link house and lack of bona fide need address s.13(1)(e) but do not effectively counter the s.13(1)(h) ground already accepted by the trial court. The statutory framework supports eviction on at least one ground.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant has two independent grounds for eviction under sections 13(1)(e) and 13(1)(h) of the Act. While lower courts rejected the bona fide requirement under 13(1)(e), the trial court found in favor of the appellant under 13(1)(h) - that the tenant built a suitable alternative residence. The appellate and High Court's findings on mixed use (residential and professional) appear to conflate the requirements of both provisions, and their alternative reasoning on 13(1)(h) regarding business suitability seems to impose an additional requirement not clearly supported by the statutory language. The Supreme Court may find the lower courts applied an overly restrictive interpretation, particularly on the 13(1)(h) ground.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether Customs Officers are 'police officers' under Section 25 of the Evidence Act, which would render confessional statements inadmissible. The petitioner's argument is legally sound: Customs Officers have revenue-focused duties (levy of duties, confiscation, penalties) rather than crime prevention/detection functions that define police officers. The precedents cited (Thomas Dana, Maqbool Hussain) support the distinction between revenue officers and police officers, even when revenue officers are granted certain investigative powers. The mere conferment of some powers similar to police (arrest, search) does not transform their fundamental character from revenue to police officers. Section 25's purpose is to prevent coerced confessions by police during criminal investigations, not to exclude statements made to revenue authorities in revenue proceedings. The appeal challenging conviction likely succeeds on the admissibility of the confessional statements.
cases.raw_reasoning: The central legal issue is whether Customs Officers are 'police officers' under Section 25 of the Evidence Act, which would render confessional statements inadmissible. The appellant argues that mere conferment of arrest and search powers does not make Customs Officers police officers, emphasizing functional distinction and nomenclature. The judgment excerpt suggests the Court is inclined toward this interpretation, noting that Customs Officers have specialized duties distinct from general police functions. Given the Court's apparent analytical direction and the principle that Section 25 should be narrowly construed to apply only to officers primarily performing police functions, the appeal is likely to be accepted.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioners have strong grounds on both issues. First, under FOB contracts where bills of lading were retained until payment and property passed only on shipment after crossing the customs frontier, Article 286(1)(b) exemption applies per established precedent. Second, the interpretation of 'a person' in s.10(b) as requiring a 'registered dealer' appears overly restrictive when the certificate under s.8(b) only declares intention to despatch, and actual despatch by any person (registered or not) should satisfy the statutory requirement. The Supreme Court's factual findings support exemption on both sales tax and purchase tax grounds.
cases.raw_reasoning: This case hinges on whether property in goods passed before or after crossing the customs frontier in FOB contracts. The established legal principle is that in FOB contracts, property normally passes on shipment (after customs clearance), which would exempt the sales from tax under Article 286(1)(b). While the Sales Tax Officer argues for an earlier passing of property, the facts show: (1) these were acknowledged FOB contracts, (2) bills of lading were retained by sellers until payment, and (3) the High Court's appellate division already ruled in favor of the sellers on this point. The Sales Tax Officer's appeal lacks strong evidence to overcome the normal FOB rule and the factual findings below.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner raises two strong technical objections: (1) non-compliance with Section 175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935 regarding proper execution of the arbitration agreement by an authorized person, and (2) the filing of an unstamped copy of the award rather than a properly stamped original, which under Section 35 of the Stamp Act and precedent (Rajah of Bobbili) cannot be validated. While the High Court found specific authorization existed, the petitioner challenges this finding as unsupported by record. These procedural and statutory compliance issues, particularly regarding governmental contracts requiring strict formalities, favor rejection of the appeal against the government.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether the arbitration agreement complies with Section 175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935, which requires contracts to be executed by persons authorized by the Governor. The notification of April 1, 1937 appears to limit the Executive Engineer's authority to instruments relating to 'execution of works' (item 2), while arbitration agreements likely fall under 'other matters' (item 12) requiring execution by Secretaries. The appellant's argument that the Executive Engineer lacked proper authorization appears legally sound, and the High Court's finding of specific authorization seems to be disputed as unsupported by record. This constitutional defect in the arbitration agreement would render it void and unenforceable.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Tribunal made findings of fact that the firms were not genuine and belonged to the same group, supported by ample material evidence. Registration under the Partnership Act does not bind income-tax authorities under s26A, and prior registration does not preclude later refusal if firms are found non-genuine. The petitioner's arguments largely challenge factual findings rather than raising pure questions of law, which the Tribunal and High Court properly declined to refer under s66.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Income-tax Officer's detailed investigation revealed substantial evidence of common control and management: the firms operated from the same location, paid rent on the same dates, used the same insurance company, dealt with the same outside parties, and extensively financed each other. The firms were controlled by two brothers (Ladhuram and Ganpatrai) and their sons, with nominal outsider participation. The systematic shifting of goods between firms and division of profits, combined with identical business operations in cloth and yarn, strongly suggests these were not genuinely independent partnerships but a single business artificially fragmented to avoid tax. The evidence supports the Tribunal's finding that these firms belonged to the same group and should be amalgamated for assessment purposes.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court has already held that Section 7 of the Limitation Act applies to partition decrees and that time runs against minors from the decree date when a joint holder (Karta) could give discharge without their concurrence. The execution application filed in 1949 for a 1938 decree appears time-barred under Section 7, as the Karta (Jawala Prasad) could accept possession on behalf of the joint family including minors in a partition matter. The petitioners' arguments distinguishing monetary claims from possession decrees and invoking Order 32 CPC protections appear insufficient to overcome the established principle that a Karta can represent the family in partition matters.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants argue that Section 7 of the Limitation Act does not apply to partition decrees and that their father Jawala Prasad could not discharge the decree without their concurrence as minors under Order 32 CPC. The High Court's grant of certificate under Article 133(1)(c) suggests substantial legal questions merit consideration. The protection afforded to minors under procedural law and the specific nature of partition decrees involving property rights rather than mere monetary claims support the appellants' position that limitation should not run against them during minority.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioners challenge the constitutional validity of the tax levy, but the facts show the Court has already determined key issues in favor of the State: (1) the tax is on passengers/goods (not fares/freights), falling within Entry 56 List II; (2) no impact on inter-state trade under Articles 301/304; (3) lump sum payment is optional through harmonious construction; and (4) no Article 14 violation as railway/road classification is constitutionally mandated and road-type distinctions are justified by maintenance costs. The cited precedents (Mathurai, Atma Ram Budhia) support measuring tax by fares/freights while taxing passengers/goods. The petitioners' textual and jurisdictional arguments appear to lack merit given the established legal framework and the Court's factual findings that the Act operates within constitutional bounds.
cases.raw_reasoning: The petitioners challenge a state tax on passengers and goods carried by road under Entry 56 of the State List, which is a valid legislative head. The charging provisions appear to be within the state's constitutional competence to levy such taxes. While the petitioners may raise procedural or implementation concerns regarding the Rules and notification, the fundamental legislative power to impose such taxation appears sound, making rejection of the constitutional challenge more likely.

cases.graph_reasoning: The dying declaration appears substantially complete as it categorically identified the appellant as the assailant before death interrupted further statement. Indian jurisprudence (Khushal Rao) establishes that a categorical dying declaration requires minimal corroboration. While the petitioner challenges the thumb impression taken post-death as dishonest completion, the substantive accusation was recorded while the declarant was alive. The distinction from Cyril Waugh is that here the identity of the assailant was established before death, unlike cases where critical facts remained incomplete. The courts below found the dying declaration categorical and sufficient, supported by circumstantial evidence of motive and medical evidence.
cases.raw_reasoning: Despite the procedural irregularity of obtaining the thumb impression after death, multiple pieces of evidence support conviction: (1) the dying declaration made to witness Muthuswami before death, (2) purchase of the murder weapon by the accused the day before, (3) accused's voluntary surrender with blood-stained clothes and weapon sheath, (4) recovery of the knife based on accused's statement, and (5) prior quarrel establishing motive. The Supreme Court appears to find the dying declaration substantially reliable despite the thumb impression irregularity, and the corroborating circumstantial evidence is strong. The appeal challenging the conviction is likely to be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's December 18, 1942 letter constituted an unequivocal repudiation of the contract by denying any valid agreement existed. Under established principles from Hunter v. Daniel and Chalikani Venkatarayanim, no formal tender is required when the other party has clearly refused to perform, as tender would be a useless formality. The repudiation occurred before the February 10, 1943 deadline, entitling the respondent to sue for specific performance without actual tender. The appellant's technical objections about the solicitor's offer and lack of tender fail because the repudiation made such steps futile.
cases.raw_reasoning: The respondent demonstrated readiness and willingness to perform the contract by offering payment of Rs. 10,001 before the February 10, 1943 deadline, sending draft conveyance, and making multiple attempts to complete the transaction. The appellant's denial of the agreement's existence after initially entering into it, coupled with the respondent's timely actions and alternative claim for redemption treating it as a mortgage, creates strong grounds for equitable relief. The doctrine of part performance and the respondent's substantial compliance with contractual obligations favor acceptance of the appeal for specific performance or redemption.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts strongly indicate rejection. The Tribunal found no pension scheme, no practice of paying gratuities, the payment was voluntary, and it was debited to appropriation account (indicating capital nature). The legal test under s.10(2)(xv) requires the expenditure be made pursuant to practice affecting salary, employee expectation, or commercial expediency. Here, none of these conditions are satisfied - it was a one-time voluntary recognition of past services without any established practice or scheme. The cited precedents (Hancock and Smith) involved situations where there was an established practice, which is absent here.
cases.raw_reasoning: The gratuity payment appears voluntary without any pre-existing contractual obligation, pension scheme, or established company practice. The employee was already well-compensated with graduated salary and profit commission, and there was no evidence of reduced salary in expectation of gratuity. Under Section 10(2)(xv), voluntary ex-gratia payments made after service termination, without business necessity or prior obligation, are typically treated as capital/personal expenditure rather than revenue expenditure wholly and exclusively for business purposes. All three lower authorities consistently rejected the deduction claim on these grounds.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central legal issue is whether the Executive Council could abandon the special Statute 30 procedure mid-way and resort to general termination powers under Ordinance 6. The petitioners have a strong argument based on the principle that Ordinances are subordinate to Statutes, and once a special statutory procedure is invoked, it cannot be abandoned for general powers. The respondent's reliance on cumulative/alternative remedies cases appears distinguishable because those involved concurrent powers, not a hierarchy where special statutory procedures were already commenced. The High Court stay on Resolution 89 further strengthens the procedural irregularity argument. While the respondent cites the inherent power doctrine, the invocation and partial completion of Statute 30 likely precludes reverting to general powers, making the termination ultra vires.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants challenge their termination under a statutory framework specifically enacted to address deteriorating conditions at the University. The Banaras Hindu University (Amendment) Act, 1958 created a special screening mechanism with statutory authority to review and terminate appointments deemed detrimental to the University's interests. The terminations were executed pursuant to this valid legislation following recommendations from a properly constituted Screening Committee headed by a High Court Judge. Given the statutory backing, the procedural compliance with the amended Statute No. 30, and the University's autonomy in managing its affairs under emergency circumstances recognized by the President of India, the courts typically defer to such institutional decisions unless there is clear procedural irregularity or mala fides, which are not apparent from the facts presented.

cases.graph_reasoning: The concurrent findings of both Sessions Judge and High Court establish that appellants formed an unlawful assembly with common object of criminal trespass and used force causing death. The petitioners' arguments about cessation of private defence rights and completion of common object face significant hurdles: the trespass was ongoing (sugarcane still being transported through the field), and the beating occurred when Harphool protested the damage to his crops. The courts found the death occurred in prosecution of the common object, making Section 149 IPC applicable. The petitioners' technical arguments about timing and cessation of unlawful assembly are unlikely to overcome these concurrent factual findings supported by the legal framework of unlawful assembly and criminal trespass.
cases.raw_reasoning: Both lower courts concurrently found that the appellants formed an unlawful assembly, committed criminal trespass, initiated the attack, and had no right of private defense. The appellants' legal arguments challenging the application of Section 149 IPC and the timing of the unlawful assembly appear to be attempts to reinterpret established facts rather than demonstrating legal error. Concurrent findings of fact by two courts, especially regarding the initiation of violence and common object, are rarely disturbed by the Supreme Court absent manifest illegality or perversity, which is not evident here.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether the Validation Act successfully validates the March 31, 1956 notification. The precedents cited (Adarsh Bhandar, Firm Bangali Mal) establish that the original notification was invalid because s.3-A was not yet in force. However, the Validation Act's purpose is precisely to cure such defects retrospectively. The textual argument about whether 'in the form...' qualifies 'notifications' or 'sections' appears resolved by the Hindi version favoring the State's interpretation (H.L.M. Biri Works). Entry 54 List II grants plenary power over sales taxation, which typically includes retrospective validation authority. The substantial tax difference (Rs. 1,26,529 vs. half) suggests the court will likely uphold the legislative intent to validate, as retrospective tax validation is generally within state competence absent constitutional violation.
cases.raw_reasoning: The petitioner challenges a notification imposing increased sales tax that was previously struck down by the Allahabad High Court as unauthorized. While the state enacted a Validation Act to retrospectively validate the notification, the petitioner argues it remains void and ultra vires. The fact that the High Court had already found the original notification unauthorized, combined with constitutional limitations on retrospective taxation and the narrow temporal scope of the dispute (April-July 1956), suggests the Supreme Court may find merit in the petitioner's challenge to either the notification's validity or the constitutional propriety of the Validation Act itself.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Act clearly falls within the protection of Article 31A as it concerns agrarian reform and ceiling on land holdings, with Presidential assent obtained. The appellants' rights constitute rights in relation to an estate as defined by Article 31A(2)(b), which bars challenges under Articles 14, 19, and 31. The petitioners' own argument acknowledges the High Court's view that the Act is protected under Article 31A is correct per Supreme Court precedents. The colourable legislation argument is weak as the pith and substance of the Act is legitimate agrarian reform for equitable distribution, not profit-making, supported by established precedents like Thakur Raghubir Singh and Atma Ram cases.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants challenge the Assam Fixation of Ceiling on Land Holdings Act under Articles 14, 19(1)(f), and 31(2). However, the Act appears to be a classic agrarian reform measure imposing ceiling on land holdings and redistributing excess land to cultivators, which typically falls under the protection of Article 31A. The High Court dismissed the writ petitions on this ground. Given the Supreme Court's consistent interpretation that Article 31A protects such agrarian reform legislation from constitutional challenges under Articles 14, 19, and 31, and the Act's clear objective of equitable land distribution by eliminating intermediaries, the appeal is likely to be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The contract for 300 tons clearly exceeds the 1-ton limit prescribed by the notification under s.4(1)(c) without the required buyer's declaration. Section 5(1)(c) explicitly prohibits 'agreeing to sell' quantities exceeding the maximum, not just actual sales. The appellant's own counsel conceded before lower courts that if the notification is valid, the defense succeeds. The statutory prohibition renders the contract void ab initio, making the appellant's claim for damages unenforceable regardless of who defaulted on the declaration requirement.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves a technical question of statutory interpretation regarding the validity of a contract under the Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950. The trial court found the contract valid while the appellate court reversed this finding. Given that the Supreme Court granted a certificate to appeal, suggesting substantial questions of law merit consideration, and that the appellant successfully performed part of the contract (160 tons delivered and paid for), there appears to be merit in examining whether the entire transaction should be deemed void. The partial performance and the technical nature of the regulatory compliance issue suggest the Supreme Court may find grounds to accept the appeal, at least partially.

cases.graph_reasoning: While the petitioner successfully established that the tax assessments on works contracts were ultra vires (per Gannon Dunkerley precedent), the Supreme Court has already held Section 14 to be intra vires and that Art. 226 petitions for refund are subject to the statutory limitations in Section 14. The Court modified the High Court order to condition refunds on whether assessment orders fell within the 24-month limitation period from August 9, 1954. Since the petitioner paid tax under diverse assessment orders over multiple years (1949-1954), many likely fall outside the statutory limitation period, making full refund unlikely despite the illegality of the underlying assessments.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants successfully obtained a declaration that the sales tax assessment on works contracts was illegal, following the Supreme Court's precedent in Gannon Dunkerley. The High Court granted partial relief by ordering refunds for amounts not time-barred under Section 14. The appeal challenges only the limitation bar on earlier payments. Given that the substantive illegality of the tax has been established and the appellants paid under a mistaken interpretation of law (later corrected by Supreme Court), there is a strong equitable and legal basis to extend the refund period or interpret the limitation provision liberally in favor of the taxpayer who paid under an ultra vires assessment.

cases.graph_reasoning: The landlords have a strong statutory right under s.14 to terminate tenancy after three years of non-payment, and s.25(2) explicitly excludes relief where default occurred for any three years. The central legal principle is that equity cannot override clear statutory provisions - authorities cannot use discretionary powers under s.29(3) or equitable doctrines like relief against forfeiture to deny landlords their statutory entitlement to possession. The respondent tenants' arguments rely on equity and discretion, but the statute creates an absolute bar to relief in cases of three-year default, and prior relief under s.25(1) does not erase the underlying default for counting purposes.
cases.raw_reasoning: The landlords challenge the High Court's application of equitable principles to grant relief against forfeiture to tenants who defaulted on rent for three years. Section 25(3) explicitly states that relief provisions do not apply to tenants who failed to pay rent for three years under Section 14. The Supreme Court's criticism of the High Court's broad equitable approach, combined with the clear statutory exclusion in Section 25(3), suggests the appeals will likely be accepted and the tenants' protection removed where three-year defaults are proven.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's primary challenge is jurisdictional - arguing the Magistrate under s.234 is an inferior criminal court subject to revision under s.439 CrPC. However, the legal framework strongly supports that the Magistrate acts as persona designata in recovery proceedings, not as a criminal court. The proceedings under s.234 are executory/recovery in nature, not judicial/criminal. The appellant's alternative arguments about appeal rights under s.93 and procedural defects in demand notice appear weak given s.222(4) deems the amount a tax and harmonious construction of ss.222, 93, and 226 supports an appeal remedy. The appellant failed to utilize available remedies (appeal under s.93) and failed to comply with statutory notices, weakening their position.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case centers on a jurisdictional question of whether the Magistrate acting under Section 234 of the Ajmer-Merwara Municipalities Regulation constitutes an 'inferior criminal court' under Section 439 CrPC, which would determine the competency of the criminal revision application. The High Court accepted the preliminary objection that the revision was incompetent, suggesting the Magistrate's proceedings were administrative/revenue recovery in nature rather than criminal. Given that the appellant's substantive pleas were already rejected by both the Magistrate and Sessions Judge, and the High Court's dismissal on jurisdictional grounds appears legally sound based on the recovery mechanism being tax-related rather than criminal prosecution, the appeal is likely to be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's challenge rests on alleged non-compliance with Section 67(2)'s publication requirements regarding 'system of assessment'. However, the facts show substantial compliance: the draft rules, schedule of goods, rates, and exemptions were published in the Government Gazette, posted on notice boards, published in local newspapers, and distributed via pamphlets in Marathi. The legal framework indicates 'system of assessment' under Section 67(2) refers to the imposition stage only, not the entire collection and refund procedure (which are governed separately by Sections 76 and 85). The respondent's argument that what was published satisfied the statutory requirement appears stronger, as the publication included all essential elements defining taxable persons/property, rates, and the assessment method. Courts typically uphold tax impositions where substantial compliance with procedural requirements is demonstrated.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants challenge the octroi tax imposition on procedural grounds, specifically alleging non-compliance with mandatory publication requirements under Section 67(2) of the Act. However, the facts show substantial compliance: the draft rules and schedule were published in the Government Gazette, affixed on the Municipal Committee's notice board, published in local newspapers, and a Marathi pamphlet was distributed. Objections were invited and considered before the final resolution. Courts typically uphold tax impositions where there is substantial compliance with procedural requirements and no prejudice to affected parties, especially when objections were actually received and considered, indicating effective notice.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether s.142A of the Government of India Act, 1935, which imposed a Rs.50 limit on profession taxes after March 31, 1939, prohibits retrospective validating legislation for taxes imposed before that date. The legal framework strongly supports the legislature's plenary power to enact retrospective and validating legislation unless expressly prohibited. Section 142A's limitation applies prospectively from March 31, 1939, and does not appear to restrict validation of pre-1939 taxes. The Privy Council's invalidation of the original tax creates a legislative gap that validating acts are designed to cure, and the 1941 Act operates retrospectively to validate taxes for the 1923-24 period, well before the s.142A limitation took effect. The precedent in United Provinces v Atiqa Begum supports that the burden lies on those challenging retrospective legislation to prove prohibition.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves a validating legislation (Act 16 of 1941) passed with proper Governor-General assent after the first validating act was struck down. The second Act explicitly validates the tax retrospectively and provides for recovery mechanisms. Indian courts generally uphold validating legislation when passed by competent authority with proper constitutional safeguards, especially when it addresses procedural defects in tax imposition. The appellant's challenge likely fails as the legislature has plenary power to validate taxes retrospectively, and the second Act appears to have cured the defects identified in the first validating attempt.

cases.graph_reasoning: The respondent established birth and domicile in India (Adoni, 1924) before January 26, 1950, making him an Indian citizen under Article 5(a) of the Constitution. Section 9(2) of the Citizenship Act vests exclusive jurisdiction with the Central Government to determine whether an Indian citizen has acquired foreign citizenship, and no such determination was made here. The State Government's expulsion order under the Foreigners Act against an Indian citizen appears jurisdictionally flawed, as the respondent successfully discharged the onus under Section 9 of proving he was not a foreigner through birth and domicile evidence.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Magistrate's conviction relied on two flawed legal grounds: (1) Section 8 of the Foreigners Act was misapplied as it applies only to determining which foreign country a foreigner belongs to, not whether someone is a foreigner; (2) The court improperly determined citizenship status when Section 9(2) of the Citizenship Act mandates that only the Central Government can decide if an Indian citizen acquired foreign citizenship. The respondent had strong ties to India (born in Adoni, family residing there, business for 10 years), and courts lack jurisdiction to determine citizenship questions reserved for the prescribed authority. These jurisdictional errors and misapplication of law favor appeal acceptance.

cases.graph_reasoning: The prosecution presented strong evidence that the preparation was not genuine Mrugmadasav: expert testimony showed 75-80% alcohol content (far exceeding medicinal preparations), absence of musk odor, and economic impossibility of using expensive musk (Rs.60-80/tola) in commercial quantities. The respondents' defense relied on a Bhopal permit which has no extra-territorial effect under Bombay law, and failed to establish the s.24A exemption. The legal framework places no mandatory requirement to consult the Board of Experts before prosecution, and the burden regarding the s.11 license falls on the accused. The evidence strongly suggests the preparation was intoxicating liquor disguised as medicine, supporting conviction under ss.65 and 66 of the Bombay Prohibition Act.
cases.raw_reasoning: The prosecution's case relies heavily on expert testimony that the seized liquid was not genuine Mrugmadasav but intoxicating liquor. However, critical weaknesses emerge: the trial court and Sessions Judge disbelieved key portions of the Excise Inspector's testimony about manufacturing supervision, and the chemical analysis could not definitively establish whether it was a medicinal preparation versus mere intoxicating liquor. The High Court's acquittal suggests reasonable doubt existed regarding whether the respondents knowingly transported prohibited liquor rather than a legitimate Ayurvedic preparation with proper permits from Bhopal State. Given the High Court's factual findings and evidentiary gaps, the Supreme Court would likely uphold the acquittal despite the State's appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant has a strong legal position based on Section 54 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which contains a non-obstante clause creating an absolute bar on courts requiring production of documents forming part of assessment records. The Presidency Magistrate's finding that these documents are part of the assessment record has not been displaced. The respondent's arguments attempting to distinguish based on third-party submission or harmonize with Section 94 CrPC appear weak against the explicit statutory prohibition and the precedent in Charu Chandra Kundu, which supports a broad interpretation of Section 54's protection regardless of document source.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether Section 54 of the Income Tax Act, 1922 protects documents from disclosure in criminal proceedings. The appellant (Income Tax Commissioner) relies on statutory confidentiality provisions that typically receive strong judicial protection to maintain the integrity of tax administration. While criminal courts have broad powers under Section 94 CrPC to summon documents, statutory bars on disclosure are generally upheld unless explicitly overridden. The High Court already rejected the revision, suggesting lower courts found the confidentiality claim weak, but the Supreme Court often upholds departmental confidentiality privileges in tax matters.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court has already held Rule 2C invalid as it does not follow statutory methods for determining annual letting value, instead using an arbitrary floor area calculation that renders the statutory right to object illusory. The petitioners challenge Rule 2C as ultra vires, which aligns with the Court's finding that the rule ignores recognized valuation methods (capital value or hypothetical tenant rent) mandated by the Act. Despite respondent citing precedents supporting area-based valuation, the Court's determination that Rule 2C violates statutory requirements under Sections 73, 78 and the definition of annual letting value in Section 3(1) strongly favors acceptance of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: Rule 2C appears to violate the statutory definition of 'annual letting value' under Section 3(1) of the Act, which requires assessment based on the annual rent a property might reasonably fetch, not on arbitrary floor area calculations. The appellants have a strong legal argument that the Municipality exceeded its rule-making powers by substituting a floor-area formula for the statutorily mandated valuation method. The District Court already found Rule 2C ultra vires, and the Supreme Court's analysis suggests the rule deviates from the prescribed assessment methodology.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Municipal Committee's appeal faces significant interpretive challenges. The doctrine of noscitur a sociis strongly supports reading 'sarso' in item 44 as a spice/kirana grocery rather than an oil seed, given its placement under 'Drugs, spices and gums' and the concluding phrase 'known as kirana groceries'. The respondents' argument that 'specific mention elsewhere' requires mention in the same character (as oil seeds) is legally sound. Additionally, the principle of resolving ambiguity in taxing statutes in favor of taxpayers, combined with the Article 14 discrimination argument (differential treatment of sarso versus other oil seeds), creates a strong case for the respondents. The High Court's reasoning appears well-grounded in established interpretive doctrines.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court's Divisional Bench ruled that sarso oil seeds fall under Item 4 (oil seeds) rather than Item 44, disagreeing with the single judge. The principle of specific entry prevailing over general entry in taxation statutes supports this interpretation. Since Item 4 specifically covers 'oil-seeds of every description not specifically mentioned elsewhere' and appears in Class I (food articles), it would naturally include sarso oil seeds unless they are specifically mentioned in another item. The Municipal Committee's attempt to levy higher duty under Item 44 appears to lack legal basis, making the appeals likely to be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's arguments face significant legal obstacles. The precedents establish that receivers can summarily enforce surrender undertakings upon lease expiry (Loonkaran v. I.N. John, Sivarajan v. Official Receiver), and receivership continues until formal discharge even post-decree. The petitioner held property under a lease from the Receiver that expired, and the legal framework under CPC Order XL Rule 1 grants receivers broad powers for property preservation. The 'just and convenient' standard likely favors the Receiver's authority to recover possession summarily where the lease term ended, particularly given the receiver's ongoing accountability until discharge. The petitioner's claim of ownership rights appears subordinate to the receivership order's scope.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's arguments face significant legal obstacles. First, the preliminary decree explicitly directed that the Receiver should continue until discharged, and no such discharge occurred before the final decree. Second, the appellant voluntarily entered into lease agreements with the Receiver, acknowledging the Receiver's authority over the property. Third, the final decree's silence on the Receiver does not automatically terminate the Receiver's powers, especially when the preliminary decree's directions remain operative. The appellant's attempt to claim ownership rights while simultaneously being a lessee under the Receiver demonstrates an inconsistent position that undermines his case. The courts below have consistently rejected these arguments, and the legal framework supports the Receiver's authority to manage and lease the property for the benefit of all parties and creditors.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central legal issue is whether a defendant can invoke revisional jurisdiction under Section 115 CPC to challenge court-fee adequacy. The established doctrine holds that court-fee adequacy is a matter between the plaintiff and the State for revenue purposes, not a right enforceable by the defendant. While Section 12(2) of the Madras Court-fees Act allows defendants to raise valuation objections in the trial court, this does not extend to invoking High Court revision powers, which are strictly conditioned by Section 115's clauses. The High Court likely exceeded its jurisdiction by entertaining the defendant's revision petition on this issue.
cases.raw_reasoning: This appeal concerns technical court-fee valuation rather than substantive property rights. The lower courts followed proper procedures including multiple Commissioner reports and detailed categorization of properties. Supreme Court typically defers to lower court findings on such procedural matters when proper methodology was followed.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether the adopted son Dhruvraj can divest the appellants of property inherited from a collateral (Narasappagouda). The doctrine of coparcenary continuation by widow's adoption supports that an adopted son becomes a coparcener retroactively and can prevail over heirs of the last coparcener. The cited precedent Anant Bhikappa Patil establishes that title to property inherited from a collateral is defeasible upon adoption by the widow of a predeceased coparcener. Since Bandegouda and Narasappagouda were coparceners, and Tungabai (Bandegouda's widow) adopted Dhruvraj, the relation-back doctrine should apply to divest the appellants who inherited through Krishnabai (Narasappagouda's daughter). The 1930 alienation issue further weakens appellants' claim as it was allegedly an unregistered gift of immovable property.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court's precedents establish that an adopted son can divest property of his adoptive father through the doctrine of relation back, but cannot divest property inherited from collaterals where succession has already vested. Here, Krishnabai (daughter of Narasappagouda) succeeded to her father's property in 1892, and it passed to her son Vasappa in 1933, then to the appellants in 1934—all before Dhruvraj's adoption in 1945. The property claimed is that of Narasappagouda (adoptive grandfather/collateral), not Bandegouda (adoptive father). Under the principle that 'inheritance once vested cannot be divested,' the appellants' title from their father Vasappa, who inherited from Krishnabai as Narasappagouda's heir, should prevail against the subsequently adopted son's claim to collateral property.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner presents strong procedural and evidentiary arguments. The respondent's son was present at the auction and subsequent postponements but made no higher offer at the time. The respondent's belated offer of Rs.9000 came three years later when market conditions had changed. Critically, there is insufficient contemporaneous evidence of grossly inadequate price - the encumbrance of Rs.17,200 significantly reduces the net value available to creditors. The allegations of collusion lack substantive proof, and the official receiver appears to have conducted the sale properly with multiple creditors present. While s.68 grants wider discretion than execution sales, judicial grounds require material evidence of fraud, collusion, or gross inadequacy, which appears lacking here.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under the proviso to Section 75 of the Provincial Insolvency Act. The provision allows the High Court to satisfy itself that the District Court's order was 'according to law,' but the High Court did not examine this question. Instead, it was influenced by a fresh offer made three years after the auction, which is not a valid basis for setting aside a properly conducted sale. The District Judge found no irregularities in the auction process, no collusion, and that the respondent's representative was present throughout without making higher bids. The appellant's argument that the High Court failed to apply the correct legal test appears strong.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central legal doctrine requires intentional disobedience with knowledge from an authentic source for contempt by a subordinate court. The appellant received information only through an unsigned application and telegram, which the legal standard deems insufficient as authentic sources requiring affidavit verification. The appellant's explanation of acting in good faith due to lack of proper authentication, combined with the tendered apology, suggests absence of intentional disobedience—a necessary element for contempt liability.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant, a Sub-Divisional Magistrate, proceeded to deliver his order on November 27, 1957 despite being informed (via telegram) that the High Court had stayed further proceedings on November 25, 1957. While the telegram was informal and unsigned, and the official court order only arrived on November 28, the appellant's refusal to even temporarily defer the matter upon notice of a High Court stay order suggests willful disregard of superior court authority. This constitutes contempt of court, as judicial officers are expected to respect and comply with orders from higher courts, even when communicated informally, pending official confirmation.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court's own finding that clause 12 operates only at the testator's death and the appellant gets no right under it since the widow survived the testator is dispositive. The Court applied harmonious construction reading clauses 11 and 12 together, prioritizing ascertainment of testator's actual intention over the avoidance of intestacy principle. The petitioner's arguments for early vesting and avoiding intestacy are subordinate to the plain meaning derived from reading the will as a whole, which shows the contingency in clause 12 was not satisfied at the testator's death.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant claims rights under clause 12 of the will, but both lower courts have consistently held that the will confers no vested or contingent rights upon him that would justify the reliefs sought. The will primarily deals with adoption provisions and property management during minority, with the appellant mentioned only as a potential adoptee - a contingent status that does not vest any present enforceable rights. The consistent interpretation by both courts, combined with the testator's clear intention to vest property rights only upon actual adoption, supports rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The critical issue is whether Article 286(3) applies. The Court's analysis reveals that while Act 30/1950 was passed after the Constitution (satisfying condition 1), the parliamentary declaration declaring iron and steel as essential goods came later in 1952. Article 286(3) requires that a state law imposing tax on goods declared essential by Parliament must be reserved for Presidential assent. Since Act 30/1950 predated the 1952 parliamentary declaration, the requirement for Presidential assent did not apply when the law was enacted. The precedents cited (Sardar Soma Singh, A. Gowrishankar) support the interpretation that Art. 286(3) applies only to laws made after the parliamentary declaration. The temporal sequence defeats the appellant's constitutional challenge, making rejection highly probable despite any merit in the broader interpretation of 'iron and steel.'
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's argument that manufactured iron and steel goods fall under the parliamentary declaration of 'iron and steel' as essential goods under Article 286(3) has substantial merit. The State's notification attempting to tax these goods after the declaration appears to violate constitutional requirements, as the law was not reserved for Presidential assent. The High Court's rejection of this constitutional challenge likely warrants Supreme Court intervention to clarify the scope of the essential goods declaration and the procedural requirements under Article 286(3).

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioners challenge the canalization policy under Para 6(h) as violating fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(f), 19(1)(g), 31, and 14. However, the legal framework establishes that canalization through specialized agencies like the State Trading Corporation is presumed to be in the public interest unless clearly proven otherwise—a heavy burden the petitioners have not met. The restriction is reasonable under Article 19 as it serves general public interest in regulating imports. Article 31 does not apply as there is no acquisition of property, merely refusal of a license. The petitioners' failure to even apply for licenses in 1957 or thereafter weakens their standing, and the court's analysis shows the constitutional provisions and enabling statute are valid.
cases.raw_reasoning: The petitioners failed to make any actual application for import licenses and are challenging a policy provision without demonstrating concrete injury. The periods for the contested licenses have already expired, making the relief sought moot. Courts typically require actual denial of licenses before entertaining constitutional challenges to licensing provisions, and the petitioners' failure to exhaust administrative remedies by applying for licenses significantly weakens their case for fundamental rights violation.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellants raise substantial technical arguments about whether the Mines Creche Rules survived the repeal of the 1923 Act and whether the manager has direct duty under Rule 7. The split opinion among judges (Das Gupta J. finding liability vs Mudholkar J. holding conviction cannot be sustained) indicates genuine legal complexity. However, the precedent in Criminal Appeals Nos. 98-106/1959 establishing that regulations survive repeal, combined with Section 24 of the General Clauses Act providing for continuity of rules, and Section 18's broad vicarious liability framework for managers in mine operations, likely supports upholding the conviction despite the technical arguments about the manager's specific duties under Rule 7.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants' primary arguments are that the Mines Creche Rules, 1946 were repealed with the 1923 Act and cannot apply under the 1952 Act due to different scope. However, the judgment excerpt indicates the court found that rules survive repeal (referencing Criminal Appeals 98-106 of 1959) and that while the 1952 Act's scope is broader, the 1946 rules can still operate as rules under the 1952 Act for mines where women are ordinarily employed. The legal reasoning appears to support upholding the conviction, suggesting the appeal will be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioners have a strong case based on violation of fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f). The cited precedent Ebrahim Aboobaker establishes that notice under s.7 is mandatory before declaring property as evacuee property. Since Khadim Ali (the actual owner) was never declared an evacuee and the petitioners as co-owners/heirs received no notice, the Custodian's declaration lacks jurisdiction. The dismissal of appeal as time-barred is a procedural matter that does not cure the original jurisdictional defect of acting without mandatory notice, and the female petitioners were not parties to that appeal at all.
cases.raw_reasoning: The petitioners were never declared evacuees nor were notices issued to them under Section 7 of the Act, yet they were deprived of their property rights when the Custodian declared the entire houses as evacuee property based solely on proceedings against two co-heirs. The fundamental principle that property can only be declared evacuee property after proper notice and declaration against the actual owner was violated. The Custodian exceeded jurisdiction by declaring the entire property evacuee when only some co-owners were declared evacuees, violating the petitioners' fundamental right under Article 19(1)(f).

cases.graph_reasoning: The customary law for Jats of Ludhiana District, as established by Rewaj-i-Am and consistent precedents (Punjab Record 1893, Chhajju v. Mehr Singh), requires two essential elements: (1) intention to adopt and (2) subsequent treatment/association as son. While Nathu executed a registered deed and made a declaration before the Panchayat, the facts show only 'short period' of cohabitation followed by separation. The precedents consistently hold that mere execution of deed without continuous subsequent treatment is insufficient. The District Judge's factual finding on this point is binding in second appeal, and the appellant's reliance on general Rattigan's Digest provisions fails against district-specific customary evidence requiring the second element of association.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether a formal declaration before the Panchayat alone suffices for valid customary adoption among Jats of Ludhiana, or whether subsequent association/treatment as son is essential. The High Court reversed the District Judge's finding, suggesting the prevailing customary law requires more than mere declaration - specifically, evidence of continued association and treatment as heir. The appellant's reliance on the general rule in Rattigan's Digest (7th edition) appears insufficient when the High Court applied stricter customary requirements. The six-week cohabitation followed by cancellation and Nathu living with the defendant suggests lack of sustained father-son relationship, undermining the adoption's validity under customary law.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts establish that petitioners hold lands from the State and pay land revenue, which the Court has already determined constitutes a 'local equivalent of estate' under Article 31A(2)(a). The precedent Sri Ram Ram Narain Medhi directly supports the Act's constitutional validity under Article 31A protection. Since the petitioners' primary argument that the Act is not protected by Article 31A fails on the established legal framework, and Article 31A protection precludes further constitutional challenges, the appeal is likely to be rejected.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court has already upheld the constitutional validity of the parent Act (Bombay Act XIII of 1956) in Sri Ram Ram Narain Medhi v. State of Bombay, specifically holding that the lands covered were an 'estate' under Article 31A(2)(a). The impugned Act merely extends the same provisions to Vidarbha and Cutch areas following the identical pattern. The petitioners' sole argument that their lands are not an 'estate' directly contradicts binding precedent on the same legislative scheme, making success highly unlikely.

cases.graph_reasoning: The critical issue is whether the plaintiff acquired valid title through the 1945 sale deed from Sitabai. However, the chain of title shows that Ram Raghu Shirsat had already transferred occupancy rights in 1892 to Laxman Chandba Raut, which eventually passed to respondent number 1 through subsequent transfers in 1903-1904. Even if the 1892 transfer violated Section 9 of the Khoti Settlement Act (requiring khot's consent), the court's analysis suggests such transfers were at most voidable at the khot's instance, not void ab initio. Since the khot never challenged the 1892 transfer, it remained valid and passed title to respondent number 1. The plaintiff's 1945 purchase from Sitabai (presumably a successor of Ram Raghu Shirsat) conveyed no title because the transferor had already parted with the occupancy rights in 1892. The principle 'nemo dat quod non habet' (one cannot give what one does not have) applies decisively against the plaintiff.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's claim rests on a 1945 sale deed from Sitabai, who allegedly succeeded to occupancy rights originally transferred without the khot's consent in 1892. However, the respondent's title derives from valid 1903-1904 purchases of those same occupancy rights. Since both the original 1892 transfer and the 1945 transfer to appellant occurred without the mandatory consent of the khot under the Khoti Settlement Act, both transfers are void. The respondent's earlier acquisition through proper chain of title, despite the initial defect, likely established superior possessory rights that were not successfully challenged. The appellant cannot claim better title through a subsequent void transfer from someone who lost rights decades earlier.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts establish a systematic pattern of deliberate starvation, confinement, and physical abuse over an extended period that caused severe emaciation and near-death condition. Under Section 307 IPC, as clarified by precedent, the act need not be the penultimate act - a series of acts constituting regular starvation with intention or knowledge that death could result qualifies. The petitioner's argument that providing funds/food satisfies duty fails when evidence shows deliberate denial of food for days, confinement, and beating. The victim's escape to hospital in critical condition, corroborated by medical testimony and contemporaneous letter describing 'death bed' condition, strongly supports conviction. The legal framework permits conviction based on course of conduct rather than single proximate act.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court made detailed factual findings that the appellant deliberately starved and confined his wife Bimla Devi with intent to cause her death, supported by medical evidence of extreme emaciation, eyewitness testimony, and the appellant's suspicious conduct at the hospital. The legal question is whether these facts establish an offense under Section 307 IPC (attempt to murder), which the High Court affirmed. Given the strong evidentiary foundation, corroborated medical testimony, and the High Court's careful analysis rejecting the defense arguments, the Supreme Court is likely to uphold the conviction and reject the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The arbitrators entered on the reference in August 1948, triggering the mandatory 4-month period under Rule 3's first alternative. The notice given on August 31, 1950—more than two years later—cannot revive their authority under the second alternative, as precedent establishes that notice must be given before or within 4 months of entering on reference. Without court extension under Section 28, the award made in October 1950 is invalid due to expiry of the arbitrators' authority, making the appeal likely to be rejected.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's argument that Rule 3 of the First Schedule provides alternative periods for making an award appears legally sound. The court excerpt demonstrates careful analysis distinguishing between 'entering on the reference' and being 'called upon to act', suggesting these are separate triggers for the four-month period. Since the arbitrators entered on the reference in 1948, then after the mother's death and delay, were called upon to act by notice on August 31, 1950, and made the award on October 3, 1950 (within four months of the notice), the award appears to be within the prescribed time under the second alternative. The High Court's rejection may have failed to recognize this alternative period provision.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant challenges the application of Income-tax Act depreciation rules instead of the Electricity Supply Act's Seventh Schedule, and contests deductions for contingencies reserve and income-tax. However, multiple binding precedents (U.P. Electric Supply, Shree Meenakshi Mills, Tinnevelly-Tutcorin) have consistently held that the Full Bench Formula applies uniformly to all industries including electricity companies, using Income-tax Act depreciation rules to maintain consistency. The doctrine of stare decisis strongly favors following these established precedents that have been applied nationwide for six years. The respondent's position aligns with settled law, while the appellant seeks to overturn well-established jurisprudence without compelling grounds.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court had previously approved the application of Income-tax Act depreciation rules to electricity companies in U.P. Electric Supply Company and The Meenakshi Mills cases, rejecting the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act method. The Industrial Court correctly followed this established precedent. Since depreciation calculated under Income-tax rules shows no available surplus for bonus, and the appellant's case depends on using the alternative Seventh Schedule method which has been judicially rejected, the appeal lacks merit and is likely to be dismissed.

cases.graph_reasoning: The charging provision under Section 3 of the Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act imposes tax on the total agricultural income of every person, and the appellant as owner remains prima facie liable. Section 13, which deems the receiver as assessee, is merely a machinery provision for recovery and does not absolve the owner from liability under the charging section. The legal principle that machinery provisions cannot limit charging provisions strongly supports that the owner remains liable even when a receiver manages the estate, and the income retains its character as agricultural income regardless of passing through the receiver's hands.
cases.raw_reasoning: The charging provision under Section 3 of the Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act imposes tax on 'every person' for agricultural income of the previous year. During Fasli year 1355, the estate was under Court Receiver management, not the appellant's control. The legal principle that a person cannot be assessed for income they did not receive or control during the relevant period strongly supports the appellant. However, the High Court answered affirmatively, suggesting there may be provisions holding the estate owner liable regardless of receivership, which is a recognized exception in tax law where the beneficial owner remains assessable.
