The High Court's approach of converting the appeal withdrawal into a petition withdrawal and referring it back appears procedurally irregular. The appellant has strong grounds on both the substantive right to withdraw and the procedural impropriety of the High Court's handling.

cases.graph_reasoning: The case involves concurrent findings of fact by lower courts rejecting both the adoption claim and the partition claim. The Supreme Court's established doctrine is to not interfere with such concurrent findings absent exceptional circumstances like violation of natural justice or shocking injustice. The petitioner bears the heavy burden of proving adoption and partition, particularly for old transactions from 1895-1905. The subordinate judge found no proof of adoption, and both courts rejected the partition claim. The will alone cannot effect severance without prior communication to coparceners, and there's no evidence Chimpirayya's intention was communicated before his death. Without exceptional circumstances demonstrated, the appeal is likely to be rejected following the principle of non-interference with concurrent factual findings.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants' case rests on two critical factual foundations: (1) the validity of Venkayya's adoption by Pitchayya, and (2) a partition in 1895 that severed the joint family property. Both the trial court and High Court found against the appellants on these issues after reviewing evidence. The High Court also rejected the alternative argument that the will itself constituted a severance in status. Without establishing either the adoption or the partition, the appellants cannot demonstrate Chimpirayya's independent ownership rights necessary to support the will's validity or the plaintiff's claim for possession. The concurrent findings of fact by two courts, absent any demonstrated legal error, strongly favor rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The suit faces multiple fatal barriers. Section 67 of the Income-tax Act bars civil courts from questioning tax assessments, and Section 25A(3) deems the HUF to continue undivided for tax purposes absent a recorded partition order under Section 25A(1), which was never obtained. The trial court's finding that the partition was 'sham' further undermines the plaintiffs' claim that their shares were immune from attachment. The statutory scheme provides exclusive remedies through appeals under Section 30, not civil suits. The precedents cited strongly support that tax liability arose at income accrual (before partition) and that civil courts lack jurisdiction to collaterally attack assessments.
cases.raw_reasoning: The plaintiffs challenge tax assessments and property sales, but face significant legal obstacles. Section 67 of the Income Tax Act likely bars civil court jurisdiction over assessment validity. More critically, Section 25A(3) prevents taxpayers from using partition as a defense against tax liability unless the partition was recorded with tax authorities before assessment. The partition deed dated March 14, 1947 appears to post-date the assessment years (1944-47) and was executed shortly after an adverse decree, suggesting possible avoidance intent. The statutory bars and timing issues strongly favor rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The critical issue is whether an unlawful assembly of five or more persons existed after four of seven named accused were acquitted. The prosecution case specifically named only seven persons, and after acquittals, only three remain. The precedents cited (Harchanda, Topandas, R v Plummer) support that conviction under s.149 requires proof of at least five members, and vicarious liability cannot be based on acts of acquitted persons. Unless the prosecution proved participation of unidentified persons beyond the seven named (which appears absent from the facts), the unlawful assembly foundation collapses, making convictions under s.147 and s.326 r/w s.149 legally unsustainable. The appeal should be accepted.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants raise a strong legal argument that with four out of seven named accused acquitted, the remaining three cannot constitute an unlawful assembly (minimum five persons required under Section 141 IPC). This directly challenges the validity of convictions under Section 147 and Section 149 IPC. The High Court's modification of conviction from Section 304 Part II to Section 326 (both with Section 149) appears legally vulnerable if the unlawful assembly itself cannot be established. Courts have consistently held that acquittal of co-accused reducing numbers below the statutory minimum undermines Section 149 liability, making this a meritorious ground for appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's arguments face significant legal obstacles. Section 2(i)(iv) of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act explicitly extends employer status to owners when work ordinarily part of the industry is contracted out, which removal of press-mud in a sugar factory clearly is. The Standing Orders definition of 'workmen' expressly includes those employed by contractors of the factory. The constitutional challenge under Article 19(1)(g) is weak as such restrictions preventing evasion of labour laws serve legitimate public interest and have been upheld as reasonable. The Labour Court's findings that the work was done through a contractor for work ordinarily part of the factory operations, combined with clear statutory language extending employer obligations, strongly support rejection of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court's analysis strongly supports the Labour Court's interpretation that the extended definition of 'employer' in sub-clause (iv) of s. 2(i) was specifically designed to include contract labour within the scope of the Act. The Court explicitly rejects the appellant's argument as 'fantastic' and affirms that the company is the legal employer of contract workers when work is contracted out. Given this clear statutory interpretation favoring the workers' position and the Court's dismissal of constitutional challenges, the appeal is likely to be rejected and the Labour Court's award upheld.

cases.graph_reasoning: The plaintiffs' claim faces fatal obstacles. First, the estate vested in the State under the Bihar Land Reforms Act on January 1, 1955, and Section 4 provides that estates vest absolutely in the State free from encumbrances. Section 6(1)(c) does not save the plaintiffs' rights because the mortgagor-mortgagee relationship ceased in 1941 upon redemption, and the defendants' continued possession thereafter was adverse, not on behalf of the mortgagor. Second, the defendants have likely perfected title by adverse possession under Article 144 of the Limitation Act, as their adverse possession began in 1941 and the suit was filed well after the 12-year limitation period. The plaintiffs redeemed the mortgage in 1941 but failed to recover possession for over a decade, allowing both adverse possession to ripen and the estate to vest in the State, extinguishing their proprietary rights.
cases.raw_reasoning: The trial court made comprehensive findings in favor of the plaintiffs on all three critical issues: (1) the land was zeraiti land, not raiyati land, (2) defendants came into possession only around 1906 under a term lease that expired in 1912-13, and (3) the suit was within limitation as adverse possession could only begin after 1941 redemption. These factual findings, if upheld, strongly support the plaintiffs' claim for possession. While the defendants appealed to the High Court, the trial court's detailed analysis of documentary and oral evidence appears well-reasoned, making reversal less likely unless significant legal or evidentiary errors are demonstrated.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant was appointed on December 14, 1953, after the revised scales came into force on April 1, 1953. Para 292 of the Sastry Award explicitly applies only to 'existing staff' appointed between January 31, 1950 and April 1, 1954, not to new appointees after the revised scales became effective. Since the appellant joined after April 1, 1953, he falls under the general provisions of Para 627 which provides for increments on April 1 each year under the new scale. The bank's interpretation appears consistent with the award's structure distinguishing between existing staff requiring pay adjustment and new appointees directly placed on revised scales.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves interpretation of the Sastry Award regarding the date of annual increment - whether it should be on the date of appointment (December 14) or a uniform date (April 1). The appellant's claim under Section 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act for computation of benefits under an existing award appears maintainable if the award's terms support his interpretation. The bank's preliminary objection about jurisdiction under Section 33C(2) may not succeed if this is genuinely about computing benefits under an award rather than establishing new rights. The substantive issue turns on award interpretation, which could favor either party, but the procedural challenge appears weak.

cases.graph_reasoning: The case presents a split decision scenario where the majority view found the accident arose out of and in the course of employment. The key factors favoring acceptance are: (1) BEST Standing Rule 19 providing free travel facility to employees can be construed as an implied term of service creating an obligation for punctuality and efficiency, (2) the notional extension doctrine adapted to bus services extends the employer's premises to the entire fleet, and (3) precedents like Cremins support finding implied contractual terms in employer-provided transport. The dissenting view that this was merely a concession is weaker given the operational necessity for bus drivers to use the service across Bombay's distances. The structured facts explicitly note the majority view favored the employee, and the legal framework strongly supports compensation liability under Section 3(1) of the Workmen's Compensation Act.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves whether an accident during transit from work to home falls within 'arising out of and in the course of employment'. The deceased driver had a statutory right under Rule 19 to travel free in uniform, which was provided to facilitate efficient service. The High Court found this created sufficient nexus between employment and the accident. The English precedent in Cremins supports compensation where employers provide transport facilities as an incident of employment, even without contractual obligation. The facility was employment-related rather than available to general public, strengthening the causal connection required under Section 3(1).

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether the agreement created a landlord-tenant relationship that would oust the cooperative arbitrators' jurisdiction under Section 28 of the Rent Control Act. The agreement appears to be an executory contract for a future sub-lease contingent on full loan repayment, not a present demise creating immediate tenancy. The Society's claim is based on loan default and membership cessation under the Cooperative Societies Act, not on landlord-tenant grounds. The mere use of the term 'tenant' descriptively does not establish the legal relationship required to invoke Rent Control Act protections. The arbitrators likely had jurisdiction as this was fundamentally a cooperative society dispute over loan default, not a tenancy matter.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court's finding that the March 26, 1952 document was merely an agreement to lease (not creating a tenancy) appears legally sound. Since no lease was executed and the appellant had defaulted on payments, the relationship was governed by the cooperative society agreement, not landlord-tenant law. The arbitration under the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act was therefore within jurisdiction, and the Rent Control Act's exclusive jurisdiction under Section 28 would not apply. The appellant's challenge to jurisdiction lacks merit on these facts.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal framework strongly favors the respondents. Section 40 orders are explicitly final subject only to appeal, with no provision for review. Section 15(3) permits review only of orders under Section 13, not Section 40. Section 47(1) of the Land Revenue Act concerns preparation of annual papers for current changes, not correction of past mistakes or reopening finalized cultivation determinations. The Nistar Officer lacked jurisdiction to review or reopen the settled Section 40 order. The procedural abatement issues further weaken the appellants' position. The cited precedent Mangloo v. Board of Revenue supports the restrictive interpretation of Section 47(1).
cases.raw_reasoning: The appeals face significant procedural hurdles with abatement issues due to deaths of parties and delayed applications to bring legal representatives on record. On merits, the appellants seek to establish jurisdiction under s.47(1) of the Land Revenue Act to correct entries and under s.15(3) of the Act to review orders under s.40. However, the High Court Full Bench ruled against them, and the respondents have strong arguments that the Nistar officer exceeded jurisdiction by attempting to reopen settled matters and review orders without proper statutory authority. The combination of procedural defects and substantive jurisdictional limitations favors rejection.

cases.graph_reasoning: While the petitioner raises a serious procedural irregularity regarding the failure to supply genuine Section 161 CrPC statements (with original jottings destroyed and fake statements prepared), the precedent in Baliram v. Emperor requires showing actual prejudice under Section 537 CrPC. The material facts establish strong eyewitness testimony from multiple injured witnesses (Ganesh, Prabhu, Mohan, Gulab) who directly witnessed Noor Khan firing the fatal shot, corroborated by medical evidence of gunshot injury and contemporaneous injuries on witnesses. The High Court properly exercised its appellate powers under Sections 417-423 CrPC to review evidence and reverse acquittal. Unless the petitioner demonstrates concrete prejudice from the procedural irregularity—which is difficult given the strength of direct eyewitness evidence—the conviction for murder under Section 302 IPC is likely to be upheld despite the irregularity.
cases.raw_reasoning: This is an appeal against conviction following reversal of acquittal by the High Court. The Supreme Court traditionally shows deference to High Court judgments that reverse acquittals when based on proper appreciation of evidence. Here, the High Court found corroborated eyewitness testimony (four injured witnesses with medical evidence supporting their presence), supported by two female witnesses, establishing that the appellant fired the fatal shot. The infirmities noted (false implication of some accused, minor discrepancies) were deemed insufficient to discredit the core prosecution case. Given the strong medical corroboration and the High Court's detailed reappraisal of evidence within its appellate powers, the Supreme Court is likely to uphold the conviction and reject this appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether Section 5 of the Limitation Act can condone delay beyond the 60-day period prescribed in Section 417(4) CrPC for private complainant appeals. The legal framework strongly suggests Section 417(4) constitutes a 'special law' under Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act, which explicitly excludes application of Section 5 to special limitation provisions. The precedent Mohammad Ibrahim v. Gopi Lal directly supports this interpretation, holding that the 60-day bar is absolute and not amenable to condonation. While there is conflicting High Court authority, the statutory language of Section 417(4) using 'shall not be entertained' creates a mandatory bar. The appeal being filed beyond 60 days without valid condonation mechanism would likely result in rejection on limitation grounds alone, regardless of merits.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case presents a clear conflict between Section 417(4) of the Criminal Procedure Code, which prescribes a strict 60-day limitation for filing applications for special leave to appeal from acquittal orders, and Section 5 of the Limitation Act, which allows condonation of delay. The High Court held that Section 417(4) is a 'special law' under Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act, making Section 5 inapplicable. Given the specific and mandatory language of Section 417(4) ('shall not be entertained'), the strict time bar appears intentional for criminal appeals from acquittals, and courts typically interpret such provisions strictly to prevent indefinite prosecution. The appellant's delay was substantial (filed in April 1960 for a December 1959 order, well beyond 60 days), and the reasoning for delay (waiting for state action) may not constitute sufficient cause under established jurisprudence.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant was a temporary employee who had not been declared quasi-permanent under Rule 3, which requires both continuous service over 3 years AND a formal declaration of suitability. The termination was effected under Rule 5 by proper notice without stigma or punishment, making Article 311(2) protection inapplicable per Dhingra precedent. The preliminary enquiry in December 1953 was not pursued to formal disciplinary proceedings, and the subsequent termination appears to be a simple contractual termination of temporary service rather than punishment, which courts have consistently upheld as valid.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's claim rests on being a quasi-permanent employee under Rule 3, which requires both continuous service exceeding three years AND a formal declaration of suitability by the appointing authority. The absence of the conjunction 'and' between sub-clauses is a weak textual argument against established administrative law principles requiring explicit declarations for quasi-permanent status. The Union's defense that the appellant was a temporary employee whose services were properly terminated under Rule 5 after unsatisfactory performance, without invoking disciplinary proceedings requiring Article 311(2) protection, appears legally sound. The trial court and High Court both ruled against the appellant, suggesting the legal position favors rejection.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioners present a strong legal argument grounded in established Mohamedan law principles that pre-emption rights do not extend to leasehold interests or superstructures on leasehold land. The facts clearly establish that the disputed property stands on Dih-Basgit Lagani rent-paying land (leasehold), and the legal framework explicitly states that 'Right of pre-emption does not exist for leasehold interest or house on such land under Mohamedan law as applied by custom in Bihar.' The respondent's arguments about modern evolution and peaceful enjoyment appear to be attempts to extend the law beyond its recognized limits, which courts have been reluctant to do given pre-emption's characterization as a 'weak right.' The doctrine requiring full ownership (milkiyat) on both sides for reciprocity cannot be satisfied when the underlying land is leasehold, not freehold.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court has already rejected two of the appellants' four main contentions: (1) the fundamental rights challenge was dismissed based on precedent in Bhau Ram v. Baij Nath, and (2) the title question was disallowed as it was not raised in lower courts and is a pure question of fact. The remaining two issues concern procedural timing of pre-emption ceremonies and whether pre-emption rights exist over leasehold property with superstructures. Given that the High Court ruled for the respondent and two major grounds of appeal have already been rejected by the Supreme Court, the appeal is likely to be dismissed unless the remaining technical arguments on Mohammedan law and ceremony timing prove compelling, which appears less likely given the lower courts' consistent findings.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellants have strong legal grounds. Section 25C does not recognize a common law right to lay-off, and the certified Standing Orders from 1950 explicitly limit lay-off to specific causes like fire, breakdown, or stoppage of power/supply - not financial difficulties or trade depression. The respondents' attempt to expand 'stoppage of supply' to include financial assistance or invoke 'other causes beyond control' for trading reasons appears strained. The precedent supports ejusdem generis construction of s.2(kkk), limiting 'any other reason' to causes similar to shortage of coal/power/raw materials, not general financial difficulties. The Tribunal's partial finding (21 days justified, 24 days not) for five companies already suggests the lay-off exceeded legitimate grounds.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Tribunal conducted a detailed examination of each company's financial position and made differentiated findings - granting partial relief to workers of 5 companies for 24 days while denying relief for 4 companies. The Tribunal's factual findings on financial distress, combined with its legal conclusion that Section 25C of the Industrial Disputes Act recognizes the common law right to lay-off and overrides Standing Orders, creates a strong foundation for the award. The appellants are challenging a mixed award where the Tribunal has already granted them partial relief based on detailed financial analysis, making complete reversal unlikely.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court typically shows deference to Industrial Tribunal awards unless they are erroneous in law. Here, the Tribunal's findings rest on factual assessments: (1) the tiffin allowance is supported by comparable concerns' practices (31 concerns providing free tiffin) and negotiation history creating an implied condition of service; (2) re-employment at lower wages undercuts the established wage structure. The petitioner's arguments challenge factual findings and policy considerations rather than demonstrating clear legal error. The legal standard for interference—'erroneous in law'—appears not to be met, making rejection of the appeal likely.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant challenges the tribunal's award on two grounds: cash allowance for tiffin and re-employment of retired persons. The appellant's primary legal argument is strong - there is no statutory obligation under the Factories Act to provide tiffin allowance beyond the mandatory canteen facility already provided. The tiffin arrangement was voluntarily undertaken after the 1956 settlement and was left to management's discretion. The tribunal's direction to convert a discretionary benefit into a mandatory cash allowance appears to exceed its jurisdiction, particularly when the employer is already providing the facility voluntarily. This suggests the appeal has merit and may be accepted, at least partially.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant has strong grounds based on established precedent that administrative directions under s.43A have no legal force and cannot bind transport authorities. The Appellate Tribunal appears to have applied a monopoly policy that may constitute an irrelevant consideration, particularly given the presence of parallel railway service and competition from Raman & Raman. The High Court under Art.226 should not have substituted its view on factual matters where the Regional Transport Authority had already granted the permit to the appellant based on highest marks. The case law cited supports that certiorari can issue when decisions rest on irrelevant considerations, which appears applicable here.
cases.raw_reasoning: The single judge found that the Appellate Tribunal failed to consider relevant evidence, specifically the competitive dynamics between the appellant and Raman & Raman P Ltd, and the parallel railway service. The Division Bench's reversal appears to apply an overly deferential standard by suggesting that failure to marshal all reasons is insufficient for certiorari. Given that administrative tribunals must consider all relevant factors under Section 47(1)(a) of the Motor Vehicles Act, and the Supreme Court typically requires proper consideration of material facts in permit cases, the appeal is likely to be accepted on grounds of procedural impropriety or failure to consider relevant evidence.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Tribunal found that the Income-tax Officer's adjustment was illegal because it was made without prior consultation with the Controller of Insurance as mandated by the proviso to Rule 3(b). The statutory scheme under Section 10(7) and the Schedule rules is strict and exclusive, requiring compliance with procedural safeguards. The respondent's argument that the proviso doesn't apply when no interest rate issue exists appears to be a narrow interpretation that conflicts with the mandatory language requiring consultation for adjustments affecting reserves. The precedents cited support strict adherence to the procedural requirements, making the Tribunal's decision legally sound.
cases.raw_reasoning: The central legal issue is whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to make adjustments to the Investment Reserve Fund transfer without prior consultation with the Controller of Insurance as required by the proviso to Rule 3(b) of the Schedule. The assessee's argument that such consultation is mandatory appears legally sound, as the proviso explicitly states adjustments shall be made 'after consultation with the Controller of Insurance.' The procedural requirement was not followed, making the adjustment potentially ultra vires. The High Court's willingness to order the Tribunal to state a case suggests merit in the assessee's position, indicating likely acceptance of the appeal on procedural grounds.

cases.graph_reasoning: The respondents have strong legal grounds for subrogation under equitable principles. The precedent Gokuldass Gopaldass establishes that no written agreement is necessary for subrogation, and the presumption that Sham Sunder intended to keep the charge alive when paying off Daulatram's mortgage (Rs. 84,000 reserved specifically for this purpose) appears unrebutted by concrete evidence. Additionally, Mukhamal's claim for marshalling under Section 56 TPA as a purchaser has statutory support. The petitioners' arguments about rebutting the presumption and prejudice to subsequent encumbrancers appear weaker without specific evidence of contrary intention or demonstrable prejudice.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court correctly applied the equitable principle of subrogation under Section 92 of the Transfer of Property Act, holding that an express agreement is not essential for a subsequent mortgagee who discharges a prior mortgage to be subrogated to the prior mortgagee's rights and priorities. This principle protects Sham Sunder's legal representatives who paid Rs. 84,000 to discharge Daulatram's prior mortgages, giving them priority over Jagdish Chand's later mortgage. The trial court's requirement of an express agreement was overly restrictive and contrary to established equitable principles of subrogation, which the High Court properly corrected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner presents strong statutory interpretation arguments on two grounds: (1) Section 17(4) of the Land Acquisition Act explicitly dispenses with Section 5A only for waste/arable land under s.17(1)/(2), not for non-waste land under s.17(1A), making the s.6 notification procedurally invalid without s.5A compliance; (2) The Kanpur Urban Area Development Act s.114 appears to mandate modified LAA procedures when land is acquired 'for the Board' under scheme No. XX. The deprivation of the substantial right to object under s.5A for non-waste industrial land (cotton mill with buildings) represents a serious procedural irregularity that courts typically remedy. The textual and harmonious construction arguments favor the petitioner's position that proper statutory procedures were not followed.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's arguments face significant legal hurdles. First, the acquisition notification explicitly states dual purposes - both the subsidized industrial housing scheme and scheme No. XX - which may allow the government to proceed under general Land Acquisition Act provisions rather than the specific Kanpur Act procedures. Second, regarding the Section 5-A objection process, Section 17(4) of the Land Acquisition Act provides an exception for urgent cases, and the notification explicitly invoked urgency provisions under Section 17(1) and (1-A), which typically allows bypassing Section 5-A requirements. The High Court's dismissal at both single judge and division bench levels, combined with the government's explicit invocation of urgency provisions, suggests the legal framework supports the acquisition process followed.

cases.graph_reasoning: The core issue is whether the rearrest was lawful. The petitioner argues release was not under conditional Rule 549, while the respondent claims it was conditional. However, the burden lies on the State to prove lawful authority for detention (per Eshugbayi Eleko precedent). The facts show ambiguity: Form 105 listed multiple rules without scoring any out, and the District Magistrate's order doesn't clearly establish conditional release. Given the fundamental liberty interest at stake and the principle that executive detention requires clear legal authority, the lack of demonstrated lawful basis for rearrest favors the petitioner. The High Court's grant of habeas corpus appears legally sound.
cases.raw_reasoning: The State failed to file a return to the habeas corpus petition and could not establish the legal authority for Bipat Gope's detention after his conditional release. The procedural irregularities, including unclear authority for re-arrest and the absence of proper documentation, strongly favor the detainee. The High Court's issuance of a rule nisi and the State's failure to justify the detention suggest the appeal will likely be rejected, meaning the habeas corpus petition would be accepted.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Labour Court found the dismissal justified on merits, holding the mistakes were serious and could have caused an aircraft accident. Despite procedural challenges regarding timing of s.33(2)(b) application and natural justice concerns about Station Manager bias, established precedent (Phulbari Tea Estate) allows tribunals to approve dismissals on evidence even when domestic inquiry is defective. The appellant was not a protected workman (mere union letter insufficient), so s.33(1) permission was not required. The substantive finding of gross dereliction involving aviation safety strongly supports upholding the dismissal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Labour Court found that the appellant admitted the serious mistakes that could have caused aircraft accidents and loss of life. Despite the potential bias issue with the Station Manager conducting the inquiry, the Labour Court independently evaluated all evidence and found the dismissal justified and proportionate to the gravity of the offence. The procedural requirements under Section 33(2)(b) were substantially complied with, including payment of one month's wages and timely application to the tribunal. The Supreme Court's precedent in Straw Board Manufacturing Co. supports the respondent's compliance with statutory requirements.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner raises substantial evidentiary challenges regarding proof of stolen property. The failure to examine writers of gate passes and invoices creates a critical gap in the chain of evidence establishing that recovered items were the stolen goods. The discrepancy regarding violet shawls further undermines identification. Under Section 414 IPC, the prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that the property was stolen and that the accused knew or had reason to believe it was stolen. These evidentiary deficiencies, particularly regarding establishing the foundational element that the recovered property was indeed the stolen property from the railway wagon, likely favor the appellant.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court reversed the acquittal based on strong circumstantial evidence: (1) recovery of 80/95 shawls and 43/63 mufflers matching stolen goods within days of theft, (2) items bearing original manufacturer labels from Kanpur Woollen Mills, (3) recovery at appellant's instance from locked premises, and (4) no adequate explanation for possession of such large quantities. While the appellant challenges proof that recovered items were the specific stolen goods, the combination of matching quantities, timing, labels, and suspicious circumstances creates compelling evidence of guilty knowledge under Section 414 IPC. The Supreme Court typically defers to High Court findings on appreciation of evidence unless perverse.

cases.graph_reasoning: The formal order dated February 16, 1948 specified definite quantities (14,000 maunds total) with specific delivery dates across four installments, transforming what may have initially been a standing offer into a binding contract for a definite quantity. The cancellation clause in paragraph 2, when properly construed in context, appears to apply only to un-ordered supplies or the pre-formal order stage, not to supplies already subject to a formal order with specified quantities and dates. The cited precedent supports the distinction between initial tender acceptance and subsequent formal orders that create binding obligations.
cases.raw_reasoning: The contract explicitly contained a clause reserving the railway administration's right to cancel the contract at any stage without calling up outstanding obligations. This clause appeared both in the tender form and in the acceptance letter, and the respondent accepted these terms by proceeding with the contract. Indian contract law generally upholds freedom of contract, and parties are bound by terms they have expressly agreed to, even if such terms appear one-sided. The courts typically enforce such cancellation clauses in government contracts unless they violate fundamental principles of natural justice or statutory provisions, which does not appear to be argued here.

cases.graph_reasoning: The retrospective application of Section 7 of the Bengal Land Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act VII of 1950 is fatal to the plaintiff's case. While the suit was validly instituted under the old Section 37, Section 7(1)(a) explicitly causes abatement of pending suits and appeals that would not be valid under the amended Act. Since the appeal was pending when the Amending Act came into force, and the defendants' tenure would be protected under the new Section 37 (as existing before the 1910 notification), the suit must abate. The plaintiff's argument regarding delivery of possession on March 29, 1949 fails because the proviso to Section 7(2) only protects executed decrees, but the suit itself abates under Section 7(1)(a) before reaching the decree execution stage. The legislative intent to protect existing tenures retrospectively in pending litigation overrides the plaintiff's procedural victory.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Amending Act's Section 7 explicitly applies retrospectively to pending proceedings, making suits that could not have been validly instituted under the new law abate. The High Court found that possession delivery was without authority (a nullity) since it occurred after the appeal was filed and without proper stay order consideration. Since the land was determined to be Lakheraj (rent-free permanent tenure) protected under the amended Section 4, the original suit would not have been valid under the new law, triggering Section 7's abatement provision. The appellant's arguments about completed execution fail because the possession delivery was deemed invalid.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal framework clearly establishes that government is not bound by enquiry officer findings and can differ from them. However, the critical issue is whether there was ANY evidence to support the bribery charge. The enquiry officer found charges not satisfactorily proved, and UPSC advised no penalty. The High Court's jurisdiction under Article 226 permits quashing if there is no evidence at all supporting the government's conclusion. Given that both the enquiry officer and UPSC found insufficient proof, and the 'no evidence' standard is well-established in precedent, the appeal challenging the High Court's intervention is likely to be rejected or the employee's position upheld.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case presents two critical issues: (1) whether the Government can differ from the enquiry officer's findings, and (2) whether the High Court can review evidence in writ proceedings. While the Court affirms the Government's power to differ from the enquiry officer (first point in appellant's favor), the judgment excerpt reveals that both the enquiry officer and the Union Public Service Commission found charges unproven. The Government's dismissal order contradicts these findings without fresh evidence. Given that the Court acknowledges the appellant 'fails on the second point' regarding evidentiary support, and considering judicial reluctance to uphold dismissals lacking proper evidentiary foundation, the appeal is likely to be rejected despite the Government's technical competence to differ from subordinate findings.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellants' arguments face significant legal hurdles. First, the natural justice claim regarding reply arguments is procedural and unlikely to overturn substantive convictions upheld by both trial and High Court. Second, the res judicata/autrefois acquit argument under s.403 CrPC fails because the two cases involve distinct offences separated by time and place - one involving Tikam's assault/murder and another involving Puran's injuries. The cited precedents (Sambasivam, Pritam Singh) are distinguishable as they involved the same transaction, whereas here the offences are separate incidents. The courts have already conducted two levels of factual review, and the Supreme Court typically defers to concurrent findings unless there is manifest error, which is not evident from the structured facts presented.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants' main argument based on res judicata from the prior acquittal in the companion case appears weak, as the excerpt indicates the Supreme Court distinguished similar precedents in Mohinder Singh and Gurcharen Singh cases. The two cases involved different victims and circumstances, and both lower courts found sufficient evidence for conviction in Tikam's assault case.

cases.graph_reasoning: The case presents strong grounds for accepting the appeal based on two key issues: (1) The procedural irregularity of revoking leave preparatory to retirement after it was sanctioned and gazetted, particularly when the appellant had already proceeded on leave - the cited precedent suggests leave once granted creates vested rights; (2) The allegation of mala fides arising from the Chief Minister's personal involvement, especially given the temporal proximity between the operation on his son and the adverse orders. The precedents cited (Lazarus Estates, Municipal Council of Sydney) support the principle that orders obtained through improper motives or for alien purposes are ultra vires. While the respondent invokes Article 310's pleasure doctrine, the Abdul Majid precedent appears to limit its scope regarding compulsory continuation of service post-superannuation. The confluence of procedural irregularities and credible mala fide allegations creates substantial grounds for judicial intervention.
cases.raw_reasoning: The majority judgment indicates agreement that the orders were within government power under service rules, but crucially finds merit in examining the mala fides allegation. The Court explicitly rejects the Attorney General's position that mala fides cannot vitiate administrative orders, comparing it to fraud or corruption. The detailed discussion of mala fides principles and the Court's willingness to examine evidence of the Chief Minister's personal hostility suggests the Court is inclined to find the orders were tainted by improper motive, which would warrant setting them aside despite being formally within power.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal framework clearly establishes that the burden of proof for cash credits lies with the assessee, as supported by the cited precedent A. Govindarajulu Mudaliar. The petitioner's arguments fail to discharge this burden, and the Tribunal's finding that unexplained credits represent income from undisclosed sources is a factual inference that is final under Section 66. The petitioner's claim of double taxation is weak because undisclosed source income is distinct from estimated business income on a percentage basis. The Tribunal's findings on facts are not referable to the High Court as questions of law.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves unexplained cash credits discovered during reassessment proceedings. The established legal principle, as cited in the judgment excerpt itself (A. Govindarajulu Mudaliar case), clearly places the burden of proof on the assessee to explain the source of such credits. The assessee failed to provide satisfactory explanations for most entries, and the Tribunal upheld the additions except for two items. The High Court answered against the assessee on the key question of burden of proof. Given the well-settled law on unexplained cash credits and the assessee's failure to discharge the burden, the appeal is likely to be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appeal is likely to be ACCEPTED based on strong legal grounds. First, the petitioners have a compelling argument that customary rights of archakas and karnam are protected under Section 79 of the Madras HRE Act, with evidence of 25 years of established practice under the 1925 scheme. Second, the High Court appears to have modified remuneration without sufficient cause or adequate pleadings/evidence from the Board, which merely conceded the dibbi share in its own petition. Third, while there is a preliminary jurisdictional issue about appealability under s.57(9), the substantive merits favor protecting long-established customary emoluments absent compelling justification for change.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appeals challenge modifications to a temple administration scheme under the Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act. The High Court modified remuneration provisions for archakas and Karnam after the Board sought changes to an existing scheme. Given that the Board successfully appealed to modify the scheme, and the cross-objections by archakas were dismissed and became final, the Supreme Court is likely to defer to the High Court's exercise of discretion in modifying the scheme under statutory powers, particularly where the modifications relate to administrative and financial matters of temple management rather than fundamental rights.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court's interpretation of Section 44 creates a legal fiction allowing assessment of a dissolved association as a continuing unit, with joint and several liability attaching to all members. The cited precedent C.A. Abraham directly supports continuity of assessment proceedings post-dissolution. While the respondent raises procedural objections about individual notice requirements, Section 44's statutory language imposing joint and several liability on members upon dissolution appears to override such procedural defects, making the assessment enforceable against all members regardless of individual notice. The appeal challenging the High Court's restrictive interpretation is likely to succeed.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court held the assessment was bad in law because notice under sections 34 and 22(4) was not served on Rajareddy Mallaram, only on Baba Gowd. However, Section 44 of the Income-tax Act explicitly provides that members of a dissolved association are jointly and severally liable for tax, and the Supreme Court's precedent in Abraham's case supports continuity of assessment proceedings despite discontinuance. The statutory language appears to override the procedural defect of non-service on all members, making the High Court's reasoning vulnerable to reversal on appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The respondent's claim appears legally sound on multiple grounds. First, the precedent Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan establishes that applications under s.33C(2) are competent for recovery of money benefits by workmen. Second, the Sastry Award's definition in Para 332 and 167 suggests accountants performing mainly clerical duties with supervision remain workmen, not officers. Third, the legal framework under s.19(6) indicates awards continue as binding contracts even after their formal operation period expires, meaning the Sastry Award's benefits would still apply to the respondent's appointment in July 1959. The bank's arguments about jurisdiction and the award's expiry appear to face significant legal obstacles based on the established precedent and statutory interpretation.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court's precedent in Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan establishes that applications under Section 33C(2) are maintainable, defeating the Bank's first objection. The Court's analysis distinguishes between an award being 'in operation' versus 'binding on parties,' suggesting that even after March 31, 1959, the Sastry Award continued to bind the parties as a contract made through industrial adjudication. The detailed legal reasoning provided indicates the Court is likely to find merit in the respondent's claim for benefits under the award, particularly given the statutory interpretation favoring continuation of award terms beyond their formal expiry.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether the Government's decision under the second proviso to clause 5 of the Surcharge Order, 1944 is final and binding. The petitioner challenges both the procedural admission of evidence and the substantive interpretation of Ex. 68. However, the legal framework explicitly provides that the Provincial Government's decision on disputes regarding surcharge applicability is 'final and binding' without requiring formal arbitration. The respondent's reliance on this statutory finality provision, combined with the existence of Ex. 68 (the Government communication), creates a strong legal basis for upholding the surcharge obligation. While the petitioner raises valid procedural concerns about evidence admission in second appeal, the substantive legal doctrine of finality under the Surcharge Order likely prevails, suggesting the appeal will be accepted to clarify or correct the High Court's approach to this statutory interpretation issue.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court reversed both lower courts after admitting additional evidence, and the appellant's primary challenge is procedural (admissibility of additional evidence in second appeal). The Court indicates it finds this procedural challenge unnecessary to decide, suggesting it will focus on the substantive merits. The respondent's defense that the Government's decision under the Surcharge Order is final and binding appears strong, as such finality clauses are typically upheld. The appellant's success in lower courts was reversed on substantive grounds after fuller evidence was considered, indicating the legal merits favor the respondent.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's appeal is likely to be rejected. While the Court accepts the appellant's claim for notional normal depreciation over statutory depreciation, the critical issue is the Rs. 60,000 notional remuneration claim for Mr. K.R. Podar. The legal framework clearly establishes that purely notional remuneration without actual payment or sufficient evidence cannot be allowed as a prior charge under the Full Bench Formula. The appellant's evidence consists only of an affidavit from Mr. Gupta (the Manager, not Podar himself) without cross-examination or documentary proof of actual services rendered. Even with corrections to the available surplus calculation (Rs. 0.39 lac instead of Rs. 0.33 lac), rejecting the unsupported Rs. 60,000 remuneration claim would leave sufficient surplus to justify some bonus payment to workers, making the Tribunal's award of half-month's basic wages reasonable and sustainable.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Tribunal awarded bonus at half month's basic wages after finding available surplus of Rs. 0.33 lac (corrected to Rs. 0.39 lac). The appellant's main challenge is the rejection of Rs. 60,000 as notional remuneration for Director K.R. Podar. However, the evidence shows no Board resolution was passed for this remuneration, Podar did not actually charge it, and the appellant itself admitted the financial position was unsatisfactory. The lack of formal authorization and actual payment weakens the claim for this prior charge deduction. The Tribunal's award appears reasonable given the available surplus and established industrial law principles requiring actual, authorized payments for prior charges.

cases.graph_reasoning: The respondents have a stronger legal position based on the presumption of correctness afforded to the Riwaj-i-am of Ferozepore, which appears to exclude adopted sons from inheriting in their natural family. The petitioners bear the burden of proving the custom they assert (that customary adoption does not sever natural family inheritance rights), but the evidence presented—including specific mutation entries (Ext D-5) showing Ghuda Singh's exclusion from his natural father's estate—supports the respondents' position that local custom in Ferozepore District operates differently from the general custom in Rattigan's Digest. The conflict between general custom and specific local Riwaj-i-am entries typically resolves in favor of the latter, and the petitioners have not provided sufficient instances to rebut this presumption.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court's finding that the adoption was customary rather than formal, allowing the adopted son's descendants to inherit in the natural family, appears well-grounded in customary law principles. The appellants failed to prove formal adoption ceremonies that would completely sever ties with the natural family. The overwhelming authority cited by the High Court supporting inheritance rights in customary adoptions, combined with the lack of evidence of formal adoption, makes reversal unlikely.

cases.graph_reasoning: The respondent has established honest concurrent use since 1928/1930 without instances of confusion, and the goods serve different end-users (women vs men). Section 10(2) provides an exception to the general prohibition under s.8(a) for honest concurrent use and special circumstances. The Deputy Registrar's finding of no likelihood of deception after decades of concurrent use, combined with the judicial discretion afforded under s.10(2), supports rejection of the appellant's challenge despite the marks being identical.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant has a strong case under Section 8(a) of the Trade Marks Act, having used the identical mark 'Durex' since 1932 with established reputation, while the respondent applied only in 1946. The marks are identical for similar goods (contraceptives), creating likelihood of deception and confusion. While Section 10(2) allows registration of identical marks in cases of honest concurrent use, the appellant's prior use and reputation, combined with the identity of marks for the same goods, weighs heavily against the respondent. The appellant's argument that Section 8(a) is not subject to Section 10(2) appears legally sound, as Section 8 provides general prohibitions on registration.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner presents a compelling distinction between gratuity schemes for ongoing versus closed industries. The cited precedents (Indian Hume Pipe and Bharatkhand Textile) establish that retrenchment compensation and provident funds don't bar gratuity schemes, but these cases involved continuing operations. The core legal principle is that gratuity schemes are designed for long-term, ongoing businesses with gradual retirements, not mass terminations upon closure. The Industrial Court's award was made over a year after the company had already closed and been taken over, making the financial capacity assessment and long-term planning basis inapplicable. The distinction between retrenchment compensation (immediate) and gratuity (long-term retirement benefit) supports that imposing gratuity post-closure effectively creates additional retrenchment compensation, which contradicts the evolved doctrine of industrial adjudication.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's argument that gratuity schemes should not be imposed after business closure has merit, as such schemes are typically designed for ongoing operations with long-term planning. The timing is critical - the gratuity claim was made only after the company's license expiry was imminent and known, and the award was made over a year after business closure. Courts have generally held that imposing new financial obligations on a company that has already ceased operations raises questions of fairness and practicability, particularly when the claim appears opportunistic rather than based on established practice during the operational period.

cases.graph_reasoning: The respondents raise substantial procedural objections regarding misjoinder of charges and persons under s.239 CrPC, supported by precedents (Vankavalapati Gopala Rao, T.B. Mukherji) holding that clauses of s.239 are mutually exclusive and cannot be cumulatively applied. However, the petitioner's position that s.235(1) has no overriding effect on s.239, combined with the court's recognition that s.537 CrPC cures irregularities absent prejudice, and the material facts showing substantial misappropriation (Rs. 3,40,000) with clear conspiracy evidence, suggest the convictions will likely be upheld. The procedural irregularities alleged appear technical rather than causing failure of justice, and the substantive evidence of criminal breach of trust and conspiracy seems strong.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves serious charges of criminal breach of trust, forgery, and conspiracy against employees in positions of significant trust and fiduciary responsibility. The respondent No. 1 held dual positions giving him extensive control over VESCO's financial affairs with minimal oversight, creating opportunity for the alleged offenses. The trial court convicted both respondents, and the State sought enhancement of sentences, suggesting strong evidence at trial. The High Court's reversal of convictions in such white-collar crime cases involving breach of fiduciary duty often faces scrutiny on appeal, particularly when the accused held positions of trust and the trial court found sufficient evidence for conviction.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner presents strong textual and harmonious construction arguments that s.389 Companies Act is merely enabling, not restrictive, allowing companies to arbitrate under ICC rules. The Protocol Act 1937 s.3 explicitly overrides inconsistent provisions of the Arbitration Act 1940 via s.47, creating a clear statutory hierarchy favoring international arbitration agreements. The cited precedents appear distinguishable as they predate or concern different statutory frameworks, while the petitioner's interpretation aligns with contractual freedom principles and India's international arbitration obligations under the Protocol Act.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether an Indian company can be compelled to arbitrate under International Chamber of Commerce rules when Section 389 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956 mandates that company disputes go to arbitration only in accordance with the Arbitration Act, 1940. The statutory restriction on Indian companies entering into foreign arbitration agreements that bypass domestic arbitration law creates a strong legal impediment to enforcing the ICC arbitration clause. The courts typically uphold mandatory statutory provisions governing Indian companies over contractual arbitration clauses that conflict with such provisions.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court already held that the villages were held under an 'agreement' per s.2(d), making them an 'estate' under s.2(b). The critical issue is whether s.3(3) saves the exemption. Section 3(3) explicitly excludes the estate-holder from saved exemptions, preserving only exemptions for 'persons other than the estate-holder.' Since the appellant is the estate-holder claiming exemption under the 1847 indenture, s.3(3) does not protect this exemption. The legislative intent to abolish revenue exemptions for estate-holders is clear, and the constitutional challenges under Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31 are unlikely to succeed given the Act's public purpose of revenue reform.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's claim rests on asserting absolute ownership under the 1847 grant, but both the Trial Court and High Court found that the indenture constituted a revenue farm or delegated state prerogative rather than absolute ownership. The Act specifically targets estates held under agreements with government and exemptions from land revenue, which directly applies to the appellant's situation. The appellant's abandonment of constitutional challenges after the Fourth Amendment further weakens their position, as agrarian reform legislation abolishing intermediary rights enjoys constitutional protection under Article 31A/31B.

cases.graph_reasoning: The High Court correctly held that the illatom custom cannot extend to marriage with a relation other than the daughter. Even assuming a valid contract existed, Indian law requires registered instruments to transfer immovable property title, and equity cannot override this statutory requirement. The petitioners' reliance on contract-based transfer without specific performance or registered deed fails against the mandatory registration requirements and Section 53A's limited scope, which does not apply here. The respondent reversioners have stronger legal grounds under Hindu succession law.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants' primary claim of illatom son-in-law status was rejected as Nagayya married a relation other than Chandrappa's daughter. Their alternative argument that a mere contract automatically transferred property rights without seeking specific performance is legally untenable under Indian contract and property law. A contract to transfer property does not itself effect a transfer; it only creates a right to seek specific performance, which was never pursued.

cases.graph_reasoning: Section 488(8) CrPC provides three alternative jurisdictional bases: where husband 'resides', 'is', or 'last resided with his wife'. The facts establish that Jaswant Singh lived with Jagir Kaur in Hans Kalan, Ludhiana District for 5 months after the maklawa ceremony, and was present in Ludhiana District when the petition was filed (having purchased property there in 1960). This satisfies both the 'last resided with his wife' and 'is' criteria within Indian territory. The liberal construction doctrine applicable to maintenance proceedings, combined with the remedial purpose of Section 488 to provide urgent relief to abandoned wives, strongly supports jurisdiction. The respondent's procedural submission to jurisdiction by filing counter-affidavit further weakens any jurisdictional challenge.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants have a strong case on jurisdictional grounds. Section 488(8) provides three alternative forums, and the evidence shows the respondent was physically present in Ludhiana district when the petition was filed, satisfying the 'where he is' criterion. Additionally, the respondent 'last resided with his wife' in Hans Kalan village within Ludhiana district for 5 months before going to Africa. The Supreme Court's emphasis on liberal construction of maintenance provisions to protect helpless wives and children, combined with the lower courts' concurrent findings on both jurisdiction and merits, strongly supports acceptance of the appeal despite the High Court's restrictive interpretation.

cases.graph_reasoning: The accused deliberately fixed a naked live wire without warning to prevent trespass, constituting a rash and dangerous act under Section 304A IPC. The right of private defence under Section 97 IPC does not extend to setting lethal traps that cause grievous harm or death (Section 99 IPC limitation). The common law principle against setting traps for trespassers, even if they are wrongdoers, supports criminal liability. The lower courts' conviction under Section 304A appears legally sound and the Supreme Court is likely to uphold it.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant deliberately created a dangerous condition by installing an uninsulated, electrically charged wire without warning to prevent trespass, which directly caused the death of the deceased. The courts below found all essential elements of Section 304A IPC established: a rash and negligent act causing death not amounting to culpable homicide. The appellant's defense that adequate warning existed through ambient lighting is manifestly insufficient, as electrical current cannot be visually detected. The findings of fact are concurrent and the legal conclusion appears sound, making reversal unlikely.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's appeal appears likely to succeed on technical limitation grounds. The key issue is whether s.12(2) of the Limitation Act applies to exclude time for obtaining the tribunal's order copy when computing the 30-day appeal period under s.116A RPA. Strong precedent (Aga Mohd Hamdani, Daropadi v Hira Lal) establishes that Article 156 applies to appeals following CPC procedure even under special laws, which would make the general exclusion provisions applicable. The respondent's appeal was filed beyond 30 days but within time if copy-obtaining period is excluded. If the Supreme Court accepts that s.29(2) operates independently (not cumulatively) and that Article 156 applies, the High Court's jurisdiction to hear the appeal becomes questionable, potentially invalidating its substantive findings on corrupt practices.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act applies to appeals under Section 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951. The appellant argues that the period prescribed must be 'different' from the First Schedule, which requires an identical appeal provision in the Schedule. The respondent counters that Article 156 covers appeals 'under the Code of Civil Procedure to a High Court,' which could include this appeal. The judgment excerpt shows the court agreeing with precedent (Canara Bank case) that even without an identical provision in the First Schedule, the 'different period' requirement is satisfied. This interpretation favors the respondent's position that the appeal was within time after applying Section 12 deductions, suggesting the appeal would be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The case centers on implied repeal, where Indian jurisprudence strongly presumes against it absent positive repugnancy. The petitioner Municipal Council demonstrates that ss.286-287 (special, local municipal powers) and s.72 (general state power) operate in different spheres and can be harmoniously construed - s.72 requires consultation with local authorities, suggesting coexistence rather than displacement. The respondents rely heavily on English precedents (Daw, Great Central Gas) which are persuasive but not binding, and fail to establish direct conflict or that s.72 constitutes an exhaustive code. The doctrine of harmonious construction and the special-vs-general statute rule favor the Municipal Council's position that its specific local powers survive unless wholly irreconcilable with the later Act.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court held that sections 286 and 287 of the Travancore District Municipalities Act were impliedly repealed by section 72 of the Travancore-Cochin Motor Vehicles Act, which gave Government or authorized authorities power to determine bus stands. However, the Supreme Court typically applies a strict test for implied repeal, requiring clear inconsistency between provisions. Here, the municipal power to construct and charge fees for bus stands (sections 286-287) appears complementary to, rather than inconsistent with, the Government's power to determine locations (section 72). The Municipal Council acted in public interest with substantial investment, and the doctrine of implied repeal should not lightly extinguish validly exercised municipal powers. The appeal is likely to be accepted.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts establish a completed contract where the vendor undertook to obtain necessary permission but wilfully withdrew the application, preventing fulfillment. The plaintiffs remained ready and willing throughout, while the defendant's own actions caused the failure to obtain sanction. Under specific performance doctrine and the precedent cited (Motilal v. Nanhelal), courts enforce contracts where the vendor assumes responsibility for obtaining permissions and then defaults, particularly when the agreement is not genuinely contingent but rather a completed contract subject to administrative approval.
cases.raw_reasoning: The trial court dismissed the suit for specific performance but awarded damages, indicating breach of contract by the defendant. Both parties appealed to the High Court, suggesting dissatisfaction with the trial court's decision. The defendant withdrew her application for necessary permission from authorities, demonstrating unwillingness to perform. The plaintiffs demonstrated readiness and willingness to perform their obligations. The Supreme Court typically favors specific performance when the breach is clear and the plaintiff has been ready and willing, unless the contract is impossible or void. The appeal likely challenges either the denial of specific performance or the quantum of damages, with reasonable prospects of modification or partial acceptance.

cases.graph_reasoning: Despite the appellant being the sole heir entitled to the money, he deliberately forged his deceased father's signature and used false documents to avoid the legal procedure of obtaining a succession certificate. This constitutes dishonest intent under Section 24 IPC (wrongful gain by avoiding legal expenses) and fraudulent intent under Section 25 IPC (circumventing mandatory legal procedures). The respondent successfully distinguishes Dr. Vimla by emphasizing the economic advantage gained through illegal means. The concurrent findings of fact regarding forgery, combined with clear evidence of deliberate circumvention of succession laws, strongly support conviction under Section 467 IPC for forgery of valuable security.
cases.raw_reasoning: The concurrent findings of fact by both lower courts establish that the appellant forged his deceased father's signature, attested it using his official stamp, and fraudulently obtained Rs. 275/-. These findings are based on relevant evidence and the Supreme Court typically accepts such concurrent factual findings. The appellant's total denial defense was rejected by both courts, and the elements of forgery under Section 467 IPC (forgery of valuable security with intent to defraud) appear clearly established. The legal merits strongly favor upholding the conviction.

cases.graph_reasoning: The case presents serious procedural deficiencies in the domestic enquiry: the enquiry officer failed to record findings and reasons, which constitutes a fundamental violation of natural justice principles that must be strictly observed in industrial disputes. Additionally, the Tribunal found victimisation based on trade union activities, which is one of the four established grounds under Indian Iron & Steel tests for interference with management's dismissal decision. These deficiencies, combined with the mala fide motive finding, strongly suggest the appeal challenging the Tribunal's order will be accepted.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Tribunal found multiple procedural and substantive defects: no formal findings were recorded after the enquiry, the conclusions reached could not have been arrived at by a fair and honest person, and the charge appeared vindictive given Jadav's union activities and legitimate request to work on familiar equipment. The Supreme Court typically upholds industrial tribunal findings on factual matters and procedural fairness in domestic enquiries unless they are perverse, and here the Tribunal's findings appear reasonable given the circumstances.

cases.graph_reasoning: The prosecution case rests on credible eyewitness testimony identifying the appellant by voice and gait in circumstances of prior familiarity, supported by the established motive from the sugarcane dispute and quarrel four days prior. While the petitioner raises procedural concerns about committal proceedings and challenges single-witness identification, Indian jurisprudence permits conviction on single credible witness testimony. The material facts establish premeditated murder with a clear motive, direct confrontation, and immediate fatal gunshot injury. The procedural irregularity argument under s. 207A CrPC, while noted, is unlikely to vitiate an otherwise substantiated conviction for a serious offense like murder where the evidence of guilt appears strong.
cases.raw_reasoning: The conviction rests primarily on the testimony of Rakkha Singh (father-in-law), who identified the appellant by voice and gait despite not seeing the assailant's face clearly. Two other eyewitnesses turned hostile and contradicted the prosecution case. While there was a clear motive (sugarcane dispute) and prior quarrel, the identification evidence is somewhat weak, relying on recognition by voice/gait in evening hours. However, both trial court and High Court accepted Rakkha Singh's credibility after seeing him testify, and the Supreme Court typically defers to concurrent findings on witness credibility unless there is gross miscarriage of justice. The Court's own statement that it will not interfere unless there is illegality, procedural violation, or gross miscarriage suggests the appeal will likely be rejected despite some evidentiary weaknesses.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant-company challenges the Tribunal's bonus award but faces significant evidentiary deficiencies. The Supreme Court precedents clearly establish that the burden of proving prior charges (rehabilitation, return on reserves) lies with the employer through proper evidence, which the company failed to provide. The Tribunal correctly applied the Full Bench Formula and found Rs. 4.63 lacs available surplus, with Rs. 3.91 lacs remaining even after the three-month bonus award. The company's arbitrary calculations attempting to show nil surplus appear to be manipulative attempts to avoid bonus obligations. The only arguable point is the wage bill calculation (Rs. 90,000 vs Rs. 50,000), but this affects quantum, not the fundamental entitlement to bonus, and the substantial available surplus supports the award even under the higher wage bill.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Tribunal awarded bonus based on the established Full Bench Formula approved by the Supreme Court. The appellant's challenge to rehabilitation charges fails because it presented inconsistent figures (Rs. 6,27,234, Rs. 5,84,534, and Rs. 10,25,021) without proper explanation or evidence. Supreme Court precedent clearly places the burden of proving rehabilitation charges on the employer with proper evidence, which the appellant failed to discharge through its sole witness who could not adequately explain the calculation methodology or basis for the varying figures.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's argument conflates two distinct legal principles: valuation for Privy Council appeals (which liberally includes interest up to decree) versus court-fee calculation under taxing statutes (which are strictly construed in favor of the litigant). The cited precedents (Mitthu Lal, Keolapati) establish that pendente lite interest is excluded from court-fee calculation unless specifically challenged. Since the appellant did not challenge the pendente lite interest award in any of the 48 grounds of appeal, and taxing statutes require strict construction favoring the assessee, the High Court's position aligns with established doctrine. The appellant's attempt to apply Privy Council valuation principles to a court-fee statute contradicts the fundamental principle that taxing provisions must be construed strictly.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court appears to favor strict construction of taxing statutes in favor of the subject-litigant. The appellant-defendant specifically valued his appeal at Rs. 13,033-6-6 and did not challenge the pendente lite interest in his grounds of appeal, indicating he did not dispute that component of the decree. The Court's analysis suggests that only amounts actually in dispute should be included in court fee calculation, and since the interest between suit and decree was not contested, it should not be included in the subject-matter valuation for court fees.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant clearly violated Section 3 by sending objectionable advertisements (Exs. P-1 to P-7) to Misri Singh. While the appellant claims the Section 14(1)(c) exception, this requires sending confidentially to a registered medical practitioner in the prescribed manner. The prosecution established that Misri Singh was not a registered medical practitioner, and Rule 6 requires both compliance with the legend AND sending to a proper recipient. The appellant's argument that he believed Misri Singh might be registered is insufficient - he had a duty to verify, especially given that Misri Singh wrote under instructions of Mr. Seth. The exception does not apply, making the conviction legally sound.
cases.raw_reasoning: The facts establish that the appellant sent Ex. P-7 (a list of medicines with descriptions and prices) to Misri Singh, which both lower courts found fell within the mischief of the Act under sections 3(c) and (d). The definition of 'publication' under section 2(d) is inclusive and broad enough to cover sending such advertisements within India. The appellant's reliance on section 14(1)(c) exemption was rejected by all three courts below, and no compelling legal argument appears to overcome the clear statutory violation established by the evidence.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant was confirmed after probation in 1952 and continuously employed for over 6 years, making Section 41 of the MSEACT applicable requiring reasonable cause and notice for termination. The critical issue is whether the appellant held a 'position of management' under Section 4(1)(a) exempting him from the Act. The facts show he was an Operations Assistant earning Rs. 1000 p.m., but was offered a specifically-created lower post of Senior Operations Supervisor at Rs. 900 p.m., suggesting he lacked true managerial authority. The multi-factor test for management position (banking powers, contracts, supervision, discipline, appointments) appears not satisfied based on the demotion offer itself. The High Court's certiorari finding an error of law apparent on face regarding his managerial status seems questionable given the factual nature of this determination, which should be within the Commissioner's domain under Section 51's finality clause. The appeal likely succeeds on limiting High Court interference.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Division Bench expanded the scope of certiorari jurisdiction under Article 226, finding an error of law apparent on the face of the record in the Commissioner's determination of the appellant's status. However, the single judge correctly held that the question of whether the appellant was in a 'position of management' was primarily a question of fact, and certiorari traditionally does not lie to correct factual findings unless there is jurisdictional error. The Supreme Court has historically been cautious about High Courts substituting their factual findings for those of specialized tribunals. Given the statutory finality under Section 51 and the factual nature of the status determination, the appeal challenging the Division Bench's expansive use of certiorari is likely to be accepted.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's arguments face significant legal obstacles. Section 15(1) of the Limitation Act applies only where execution is stayed by injunction or court order, which did not occur here—the composition scheme was a voluntary arrangement that did not legally stay the decree. The letter of April 19, 1949 refers only to trustees' liability under the composition, not the defendant's personal liability under the original decree, failing to satisfy Section 19's requirements for acknowledgment. The composition could not be certified as an adjustment under Order XXI Rule 2 CPC beyond the permitted time. The cited precedents involve actual court-ordered stays, distinguishable from this voluntary composition arrangement. The execution applications appear time-barred under ordinary limitation principles.
cases.raw_reasoning: The key issue is whether execution applications filed after 3 years are time-barred. The appellants' argument likely centers on the composition deed creating a continuing obligation and suspending limitation, as the trustees were empowered to extend time and the Burma assets were to be exhausted first. The composition deed's acceptance by the insolvency court and its specific provisions regarding sequencing of asset realization (Burma first, then India) suggest the limitation period may have been tolled or extended. Given the extraordinary circumstances (political changes in Burma preventing asset realization) and the structured payment scheme under court-sanctioned composition, there are strong equitable and legal grounds for finding the applications within time.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Union of India failed to establish sufficient cause under Order XXII Rule 9 CPC. The facts show the Union took the wrong legal position that limitation runs from knowledge of death rather than actual death, the affidavit was based on belief not knowledge, and no evidence was provided showing absence of negligence or reasons why they could not have discovered the death earlier. The precedent in Firm Dittu Ram Eyedan directly supports that mere ignorance of death is insufficient cause. Additionally, there is a procedural defect as the Union did not first seek a certificate from the High Court before approaching the Supreme Court under Order XIII Rule 2 of Supreme Court Rules 1950.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Union of India's application for substitution was dismissed on procedural grounds related to limitation and sufficient cause under Order XXII. However, the High Court appears to have made factual errors in its order, including mischaracterizing the application as being under Rule 9 (setting aside abatement) when it was actually under Rule 4 (substitution), and incorrectly stating reasons for delay. The Supreme Court has noted these errors and appears inclined to examine whether the High Court's dismissal was justified given these misapprehensions.
