The addition of Mahabalkumari and the two daughters as parties under Order 1 Rule 10(2) CPC would be deemed a new suit under Section 22 of the Limitation Act as regards them. Under Article 132 of the Indian Limitation Act 1908 (applicable to anomalous mortgages), the limitation period would have expired. The appellant's arguments that Article 133 of the repealed Hyderabad Act (30-year period) continues to apply, or that Article 147 applies instead, appear weak given the legal framework and precedents cited. The procedural defects in adding parties after limitation has expired strongly favor rejection of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court appears to find serious procedural irregularities in the High Court's order adding parties under Order 1 Rule 10 CPC. The Chief Justice's opinion indicates that the addition of Mahabalkumari as plaintiff and the sisters as defendants was improper because: (1) sub-rule 1 does not permit addition of defendants, (2) adding only the plaintiff would be futile without adding defendant sisters, and (3) under sub-rule 2, Section 22 of Limitation Act would apply making the suit time-barred as to added parties. The High Court's reliance on Ravji v. Mahadev regarding non-application of limitation appears to be questioned. These fundamental procedural errors affecting the validity of the decree suggest the appeal will likely be accepted and the High Court's judgment set aside or remanded.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellants' argument relies on a strict textual interpretation that the absence of express cancellation power in s.426 precludes use of inherent powers under s.561A. However, the cited precedents consistently establish that High Courts possess inherent power to cancel bail to prevent abuse of process, even where statutory provisions lack explicit cancellation clauses. The material facts show appellants committed multiple offences (Crimes 360/1965, 53/1966, 54/1966) while on bail, demonstrating clear abuse of bail liberty. The precedents directly support the High Court's authority to cancel bail under s.561A when bail is misused, making the appeal likely to be rejected despite the legislative silence in s.426.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants were convicted of bailable offences and granted bail under Section 426 pending appeal. The State sought cancellation of bail under Sections 498(2) and 561A based on allegations of misuse of liberty, violence, and labor unrest. The legal issue centers on whether the High Court has inherent power under Section 561A to cancel bail in bailable offences. Given the serious allegations of continued criminal activity and breach of peace supported by police affidavit, and the established principle that bail can be cancelled when misused to commit further offences or obstruct justice, the High Court's cancellation order is likely to be upheld. The appeals challenging this cancellation would therefore be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant faces strong evidence of violating the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952. The material facts establish that the appellant was not a member of any recognised association yet advertised and conducted forward contract business, directly violating sections 21(d) and (e). The appellant's defense that he operated through the 'pucca adatia' system fails because precedents (Bhagwandas cases) establish that a pucca adatia acts as principal-to-principal with no privity to association members, thus cannot satisfy section 15's requirement that contracts be 'between or through' members. The court's application of the mischief rule to interpret section 2(c) broadly to include speculative contracts ostensibly for delivery strengthens the prosecution's case. The cheating charge under section 420 IPC is supported by the false representation in Ex.P-34 that appellant could lawfully conduct forward business. The procedural objection under section 361 CrPC appears minor and curable under section 537 CrPC. The convergence of statutory violations, precedent against the pucca adatia defense, and evidence of fraudulent inducement strongly suggests the appeal will be rejected.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant was convicted under Section 420 IPC and Section 21(d) and (e) of the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952. The facts establish that the appellant falsely represented his ability to lawfully conduct forward contract business despite not being a member of any recognized association, inducing P.W. 2 to part with Rs. 12,000. The courts below found dishonest inducement and cheating proven. The appellant's arguments challenging the conviction appear weak on legal merits, as the false representation and resulting deception are clearly established. The High Court's rejection of the revision petition suggests strong legal grounds supporting the conviction.

cases.graph_reasoning: Section 90 of the Probate and Administration Act, 1881 grants executors broad powers to deal with estate property unless explicitly restricted by the will. The petitioner's argument relies on the principle expressum facit cessare tacitum - that express authorization to sell excludes other powers like leasing. However, the cited precedent (Purna Chandra Bakshi) directly contradicts this interpretation, holding that specific authorization does not imply prohibition of other dealings. The legal framework requires clear, unambiguous language to restrict executrix powers, which appears absent here. The petitioner's textual interpretation of clause 4 faces an uphill battle against both statutory presumption and binding precedent favoring broad executrix authority.
cases.raw_reasoning: The central issue is whether Sukheswari, as executrix with a life interest, had the power to grant a perpetual Mourashi Mokrari lease. Under Indian law, a life tenant generally cannot create interests extending beyond their lifetime without express authorization. The will gave Sukheswari the property 'for her natural life' with remainder to Nilkantha, suggesting limited powers. While the lease was executed pursuant to a court decree for specific performance, this doesn't necessarily validate a lease that exceeds her legal authority as life tenant. The plaintiffs, as successors to the remainder interest, have strong grounds to challenge the lease's validity beyond Sukheswari's lifetime.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appeal faces two critical weaknesses. First, Section 112 of the Evidence Act creates a strong presumption of paternity during marriage that requires proof of non-access to rebut - mere denial by notice is insufficient, and the respondent's arguments don't demonstrate this heavy burden was met. Second, while Hindu law permits gifts of ancestral immovable property to daughters for pious purposes, the gift to Ammathayee (the wife) of joint family property appears invalid under established doctrine prohibiting such gifts to wives. The concurrent findings of lower courts on paternity and the legal prohibition on ancestral property gifts to wives strongly favor rejection of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: There are concurrent findings of fact by both the trial court and High Court that the plaintiff-respondent is the legitimate son of Rangaswami Chettiar, supported by Section 112 of the Indian Evidence Act which creates a strong presumption of legitimacy. The Supreme Court ordinarily does not interfere with concurrent findings of fact unless there is substantial error. The appellants failed to discharge the heavy burden of proving non-access, and the gift deed to the wife of joint family property was held invalid by both lower courts, making the appeal likely to be dismissed.

cases.graph_reasoning: The core issue is whether the forest authorities' inaction in seizing the trees under Section 83 of the Forest Act after Jagatram removed them without paying instalments constitutes 'parting with security' under Section 141 of the Contract Act. The statutory charge under Section 83 created a first charge on the forest produce, giving the creditor a valuable security. By allowing Jagatram to remove nearly all trees without enforcing this charge, the authorities effectively lost the security that would have protected both the State and the sureties' subrogation rights. The cited precedents (Wulff and Billing, Rees v Barrington) support discharge of sureties when creditors lose or fail to preserve securities. The respondent's argument that the authorities' omission impaired the surety's remedy appears legally sound under Section 141.
cases.raw_reasoning: The surety's primary argument is that the forest authorities were negligent in allowing the contractor to remove trees without ensuring payment of subsequent instalments, thereby impairing the surety's remedy against the principal debtor. Under established principles of suretyship law (Section 141 of the Indian Contract Act), a surety is discharged when the creditor's conduct impairs the surety's eventual remedy. Both lower courts found that forest officers failed to exercise their duty under Rule 8 to stop removal when the value of removed produce exceeded paid instalments. This negligence allowed the contractor to remove almost all trees while defaulting on three instalments, leaving the surety with no security to fall back upon. The creditor's failure to protect the surety's interests by timely action appears to constitute a valid ground for discharge.

cases.graph_reasoning: The material facts strongly establish acceptance of Rs.10,000 by a public servant in circumstances highly indicative of bribery: confidential letter demanding money, negotiations through intermediary, prearranged raid, recovery of exact amount, and immediate explanation as 'loan' only upon discovery. Under Section 4(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, mere receipt of gratification other than legal remuneration raises a presumption of illegal gratification. The appellant's defense of a loan for purchasing a bungalow appears weak given the suspicious circumstances, clandestine meeting at night, and lack of documentation. The appellant must rebut this presumption by preponderance of probability, which the circumstances suggest he failed to do. The prosecution's case appears strong enough to sustain conviction beyond reasonable doubt.
cases.raw_reasoning: The prosecution established that the appellant received Rs. 10,000 which was not legal remuneration, triggering the statutory presumption under Section 4(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. Both the trial court and High Court found the appellant's defense of receiving a loan to be false and held the money was illegal gratification. The Supreme Court's own precedents cited support raising the presumption upon proof of receipt of non-legal remuneration, and the appellant failed to rebut this presumption with credible evidence.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's arguments face significant legal hurdles. First, the single conspiracy charge appears sustainable under Indian law where there is a general scheme with common object (issuing licences to fictitious firms for pecuniary advantage), even if executed through multiple transactions. Second, the postman Karmik acting in official capacity is unlikely to be deemed an accomplice requiring corroboration. Third, the absence of handwriting expert evidence is not fatal where direct testimony exists, and no adverse inference arises without evidence of deliberate suppression. The courts below have concurrent findings on facts, which Supreme Court typically respects absent perversity.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant challenges the conviction on multiple grounds including the nature of conspiracy charged versus proved, accomplice testimony reliability, and evidentiary procedures. However, the court's analysis distinguishes this case from R. v. Griffith by establishing a single overarching conspiracy to issue licenses to fictitious firms for shared pecuniary benefit, rather than multiple separate conspiracies. The prosecution established delivery of licenses to the appellant through postal witness testimony, and the court found sufficient evidence of the appellant's participation in the general conspiracy scheme. The technical objections regarding handwriting expert testimony and procedural matters appear insufficient to overcome the substantive evidence of conspiracy participation.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner challenges the assessing authority's decision to allow higher expenses than claimed by the respondent. However, the facts show the Supreme Court already held the assessing authority had 'full justification' in estimating allowable expenditure at a higher figure. Section 6(2)(b)(iv) permits deductions for expenses incurred without requiring proof of actual payments, and Rule 13 merely provides principles without fettering the statutory power to arrive at correct expense figures. The petitioner's narrow interpretation of Rule 13 conflicts with the broader statutory mandate under Section 6(2)(b)(iv), making rejection of this appeal likely.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves a procedural and substantive issue regarding agricultural income tax assessment. The assessing authority allowed deductions of Rs. 8,210 against actual claimed expenses of Rs. 5,769, which appears legally problematic as it exceeds what was claimed and spent. The State's revision application challenges this excess deduction. Given that the assessing authority appears to have erred by allowing expenses beyond what was claimed and actually incurred, and the matter was referred to the High Court for opinion on this legal question, there is a strong likelihood the appeal would be accepted to correct this apparent error in assessment methodology.

cases.graph_reasoning: The payment of Rs. 35,000 was made to cancel contracts for purchasing textile machinery, which would have been a capital asset. The legal framework clearly establishes that compensation paid to avoid acquiring capital assets constitutes capital expenditure, not revenue expenditure deductible under section 10(2)(xv) of the IT Act 1922. The cited precedent Countess Warwick Steamship Co. Ltd. v. Ogg directly supports this classification, and the petitioner's argument that the payment was made 'in the interest of business' is insufficient to convert capital expenditure into allowable business expenditure.
cases.raw_reasoning: The compensation paid for cancellation of contracts for capital assets (machinery) is typically treated as capital expenditure, not revenue expenditure. Under section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act, only expenditure incurred wholly and exclusively for business purposes as revenue expenditure is deductible. Since the machinery was intended for expansion (capital purpose) and the payment arose from cancelling acquisition of capital assets, it would likely be characterized as capital loss, not deductible business expenditure. The consistent rejection by all three tax authorities strengthens this interpretation.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central legal issue is whether the unregistered Relinquishment Deed invalidates the partnership registration. The petitioner's argument is strongly supported by established precedent (Addanki Narayanappa, Ajudhia Pershad) that a partner's interest in firm assets is movable property requiring no registration, even when the firm owns immovables. The doctrine of severability further supports validity for movables. The Tribunal's rejection based solely on non-registration of the Relinquishment Deed appears legally flawed. While the respondent challenges genuineness, the Supreme Court typically defers to Tribunal findings on factual matters, and the legal question of whether registration was required for the transfer favors the petitioner. The capital contribution of Rs. 50,000 by Kamla Town Trust also evidences genuine partnership intent.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court ruled in favor of the respondent firm, finding no legal flaw in the partnership constitution and allowing registration under Section 26A. The department's case rested primarily on the unregistered relinquishment deed's inability to transfer immovable property, but the High Court explicitly noted 'admissions made on behalf of the department' and concluded the partnership legally came into existence. Given that the appeal is by the revenue department (appellant) challenging this favorable ruling for the assessee (respondent), and the High Court's findings appear well-reasoned on the facts presented, the Supreme Court is likely to reject the revenue's appeal and uphold the registration.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether the new unit was 'set up' before or after the Wealth-tax Act's commencement on 1-4-1957. The facts show substantial establishment activities (orders placed, construction commenced) before this date, but the unit became operational only in June 1958 when the factory licence was obtained. The precedent from Western India Vegetable Products establishes that 'set up' means when the unit is ready to commence business, not when preliminary operations begin. Since the unit was set up (ready to operate) after 1-4-1957, it satisfies the principal clause of section 5(1)(xxi). The petitioner's new argument about simultaneous commencement of operations appears procedurally barred as it wasn't raised before the Tribunal, per Scindia Steam Navigation precedent. The respondent's position aligns with established interpretation and procedural requirements.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court's analysis strongly supports the High Court's interpretation that 'set up' means when a unit is ready to commence business, not merely when initial operations begin. The Court distinguished between 'operations for establishment' (proviso) and actual 'setting up' (main clause), finding them to be different stages. Since the Court appears to agree with the High Court's reasoning that the unit was not yet 'set up' as of the valuation date (September 1956) when only initial steps had been taken, and the factory only became operational in 1958, the appeal challenging the High Court's decision in favor of the taxpayer is likely to be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal framework strongly supports that a Hindu undivided family under Section 3 of the Income-tax Act includes a single male coparcener with female members (widowed mother and sisters) entitled to maintenance. The cited precedents, particularly Kalyanji Vithaldas and Gomedalli Laksminarayan, establish that HUF is broader than coparcenary and can exist with one male member and females. The petitioner's arguments rely on narrow interpretations already rejected by binding precedent. The procedural objection under Section 26(2) and the Finance Act exemption argument appear weak against the substantive legal position that joint family property remains assessable as HUF even when represented by a single coparcener.
cases.raw_reasoning: The legal precedent from Kalyanji Vithaldas clearly establishes that a Hindu undivided family under the Income-tax Act is broader than a Hindu coparcenary and can consist of a single male member with widows of deceased coparceners. The appellant's arguments that there must be at least two male members or that only a Hindu coparcenary qualifies as an assessable entity contradict established judicial interpretation. The lower courts' decisions appear legally sound based on the statutory language and binding precedent.

cases.graph_reasoning: The estate of the deceased appellant Dolai was sufficiently represented by his widow and major son before the Subordinate Judge, with no evidence of fraud, collusion, or unfair trial. The cited precedents (Daya Ram, Mohd. Sulaiman) establish that where legal representatives are substituted in good faith after diligent inquiry and the estate is adequately represented, the appeal does not abate merely because all heirs were not impleaded. The High Court's finding of total abatement appears to be an overly technical approach that conflicts with established Supreme Court doctrine on sufficient representation.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court's precedents in Daya Ram v. Shyam Sundari and N.K. Mohd. Sulaiman Sahib cases establish that where legal representatives are brought on record in good faith without fraud or collusion, the appeal should not abate merely because all heirs were not substituted. The widow and major son were legitimate legal representatives brought on record within time, and there is no allegation of fraud. The High Court's strict interpretation requiring all heirs appears inconsistent with the Supreme Court's earlier liberal approach favoring substantive justice over technical procedural requirements.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal framework strongly supports the insurer's right to cancel under Condition 10. The precedents establish that cancellation clauses in insurance policies allow termination at will without requiring reasons, and courts will not inquire into the insurer's motives. The critical factual finding is that cancellation occurred on July 6, 1950, when the houses were still 400-500 feet from erosion and no loss had commenced or become inevitable. The respondent's argument that erosion had commenced appears factually weak, and the doctrine that Condition 10 applies to all risks (not just fire) is well-established. The cover note explicitly incorporated the usual policy conditions, making Condition 10 applicable even before formal policy issuance.
cases.raw_reasoning: The insurance company accepted the proposal and issued interim protection cover notes for flood and erosion risks, collecting the premium. When the insured risk (river erosion) materialized, the company attempted to cancel the policy retroactively citing Condition 10. However, Condition 10 allows cancellation 'at any time' with notice, but the company's attempt to cancel after the insured event had already commenced appears to be in bad faith and defeats the very purpose of the insurance contract. The assured had no opportunity to obtain alternative coverage once erosion began, making the cancellation unconscionable and likely a breach of contract.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court appears to have settled the critical legal issue regarding the standard of proof in civil cases involving bribery allegations, adopting the preponderance of probability standard rather than beyond reasonable doubt. The Full Bench finding that the agreement was a bribe has been upheld on this civil standard, with defendants discharging their burden of proof. The appellant's main arguments challenging evidence sufficiency and procedural admissibility appear insufficient to overcome the concurrent findings of fact by lower courts that the agreement was tainted by bribery, making it unenforceable for specific performance.
cases.raw_reasoning: The facts strongly suggest the agreement was a bribe to influence the plaintiff's report as a member of the Enquiry Committee. Govindram offered the partnership immediately after the award and just before the Committee's final report, which turned favorable despite an unfavorable interim report. The timing, plaintiff's lack of experience in mill management, and the fact that a similar offer to another Committee member (Mr. Jall) was rejected as improper, all indicate the agreement was tainted by illegality. Courts typically refuse specific performance of agreements that are illegal or against public policy, particularly those involving corruption of public or quasi-public duties.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal framework strongly supports the respondent. Rule 27 appears validly framed under the Regulation Order, which continues under Article 357(2)'s saving clause. Precedents establish that compulsory retirement after specified age/service does not constitute removal under Article 311, negating the petitioner's primary constitutional challenge. The petitioner's jurisdictional arguments about lapse of delegation face the hurdle that Article 357(2) is liberally construed to preserve 'things done' including ongoing administrative frameworks. The respondent's position aligns with established jurisprudence on compulsory retirement and saving clauses.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case challenges the validity of Rule 27 permitting compulsory retirement without reasons after 10 years of service. While the appellant argues this violates Article 311 requiring a hearing before dismissal/removal, Indian courts have historically distinguished compulsory retirement from dismissal/removal, holding that premature retirement under validly framed service rules does not attract Article 311 protections. The rule was framed under express statutory authority (Regulation Order, 1954) by the Board of Directors, and the explanation limits its application to cases of inefficiency or misconduct where formal charges are undesirable. The trial court's favorable findings appear vulnerable on appeal given established jurisprudence upholding such retirement provisions.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioners challenge the land acquisition primarily on grounds of excessive delegation under s.3(4) of the Commissioners Act and lack of presidential assent. However, the legal framework shows the majority upheld the delegation as valid with sufficient policy guidance (citing Harishankar Bagla), and the public purpose of industrial/residential development is well-established and benefits the community. The procedural requirements under ss.4, 5A, and 6 appear to have been followed. The petitioners' constitutional challenges face significant precedential hurdles, making rejection more likely.
cases.raw_reasoning: The petitioners challenge land acquisition proceedings on grounds of vague public purpose and procedural irregularities. However, the amendments to the Land Acquisition Act explicitly expanded the definition of 'public purpose' to include development of areas for industrial and residential use, which directly covers the stated purpose here. The Court typically defers to legislative amendments that broaden acquisition powers for development purposes, and the procedural requirements under sections 4, 5A, and 6 appear to have been followed. The personal hardship argument regarding remaining land is unlikely to override the statutory public purpose definition.

cases.graph_reasoning: Section 24 of the Consolidation Act explicitly preserves 'the same rights and obligations' in allotted land as attached to the original holding. The precedents establish that pre-emption is a disability/limitation on ownership that runs with the land. The petitioners' textual argument that s.24 only preserves 'rights' and not 'obligations' contradicts the plain language stating 'rights and obligations.' Section 25's specific provision for leases/mortgages does not exclude the general preservation of ownership incidents like pre-emption under s.24. The respondents' position aligns with both statutory text and the doctrine that pre-emption disabilities attach to substituted land.
cases.raw_reasoning: Section 24 of the Act explicitly preserves all rights in land allotted through consolidation as existed in the original holding. The Supreme Court's own precedent in Audh Behari Singh establishes that pre-emption rights run with the land as an incident of property. Since the consolidation statute mandates continuity of rights, and pre-emption is a property incident rather than merely a personal right, the pre-emptor's remedial right to follow the property should extend to consolidated land. The appellants' argument that only the exact sold property can be followed conflicts with the statutory preservation of rights in Section 24.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts establish that the first two conditions of s.5(1)(a) are fulfilled, and the Supreme Court's legal analysis clearly indicates that the third condition does not require personal use by the tenant - only that the structure be 'adapted for residential or business purposes.' The buildings constructed serve residential and business purposes regardless of whether occupied by the tenant personally or let out to sub-tenants. The respondent's argument about sub-tenant protection appears misconceived as the protection under s.5(1)(a) is for the tenant of the land (Biswambar Roy's successors), not the sub-tenants. The literal interpretation favored by the Court supports the appellant's position that letting out does not forfeit protection.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court likely granted special leave due to the significant split in the High Court on statutory interpretation. The liberal interpretation that structures serving residential/business purposes qualify for protection regardless of who occupies them appears more aligned with tenant protection legislation's remedial purpose. The Court would likely favor the broader interpretation to effectuate legislative intent.

cases.graph_reasoning: The core issue is whether the High Court erred in refusing a certificate under Article 133(1)(a) and (b). The appellant presents strong procedural grounds: the High Court reversed the trial court's decree, and the property's value appears to exceed Rs. 20,000/- based on rental income and capitalization evidence (annual rent of Rs. 1,126-6-0 in 1950, increasing to Rs. 1,672.32 in 1961). The High Court's reasoning that temple property is incapable of valuation conflicts with established principles that valuation should be based on the plaintiff's claim in the plaint. The Supreme Court's emphasis on requiring a proper valuation inquiry under Order 45 Rule 1 CPC suggests the High Court failed to properly assess whether the certificate requirements were met, making acceptance of this procedural appeal likely.
cases.raw_reasoning: This appeal concerns a procedural matter regarding the High Court's refusal to grant a certificate under Article 133(1)(a) and (b) for appeal to the Supreme Court. The appellant had already won in the District Court, which held the premises were private property and not a temple. The High Court refused the certificate, likely finding the matter did not meet the jurisdictional thresholds (property value or substantial question of law). Since the appellant already obtained favorable relief in the District Court and is merely seeking to challenge the procedural refusal of a certificate, and given that special leave appeals on such procedural grounds typically face high scrutiny, the appeal is likely to be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellants face significant legal obstacles. First, their adverse possession claim fails as they possessed the land for only 11 years (1934-1945), less than the required 12-year period, and could not prove tacking with prior tenant possession. Second, the retrospective application of the 1947 Act's provisos, as established in cited precedents (Vishwanath, Hiraman Ratan, Basavanppa), validates the addition of parties post-limitation under s.46, undermining their jurisdictional challenge. The courts below consistently found against them on both adverse possession and the validity of adding parties. Their argument that the transaction was void ab initio and thus outside s.55(6)(b) Transfer of Property Act protection appears to be their strongest point, but the overall weight of authority and factual findings favors rejection of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants raise a strong jurisdictional argument that the application was filed beyond the 18-month limitation period under the repealed Act, and they were added as parties after this period expired. This creates a fundamental jurisdictional defect that would typically invalidate subsequent proceedings. Additionally, the appellants claim adverse possession from 1934 to 1945, which if established, would give them vested property rights that cannot be disturbed. The High Court's summary rejection of the revision and the procedural irregularities in adding parties suggest the lower courts may have overlooked these critical jurisdictional issues.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's argument that the December 21, 1949 agreement created a valid sub-partnership that diverted income before it accrued to Murlidhar personally is supported by established precedent (Sitaldas Tirathdas, Ratilal B Daftri). The agreement created an overriding title whereby the sons and grandson had legally enforceable rights to the income from Murlidhar's share in Basantlal Ghanshyamdas. While the respondent argues against double application of Section 23(5)(a), the sub-partnership doctrine recognizes that income can be diverted at source through a superior obligation before reaching the individual partner. The real income principle supports taxing the entity with actual beneficial ownership (Fatehchand Murlidhar firm) rather than the nominal recipient (Murlidhar individually).
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether profits from Murlidhar Himatsingka's partnership share in Basantlal Ghanshyamdas can be assigned to Fatehchand Murlidhar firm for tax purposes. Under Section 23(5)(a) of the Income Tax Act, a partner's share in a registered firm must be assessed in the partner's individual hands. The arrangement appears to be a subsequent disposition of profits after they were earned, rather than a genuine assignment of the partnership interest itself. The capital and liabilities remained exclusively with Murlidhar Himatsingka (Clause 5), suggesting the assignment was merely for profit-sharing purposes and not a true transfer of partnership rights. Courts typically disregard such arrangements as tax avoidance mechanisms.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court found that the land was forest land with numerous trees (Tendu, Asan, etc.), not waste or arable land as required under s.17(1) and s.17(4) of the Land Acquisition Act. This is a jurisdictional fact that can be reviewed via certiorari. Since the statutory precondition for invoking s.17 urgency provisions was not met, the notifications under s.4, s.6, and the direction under s.17(4) dispensing with s.5A were held ultra vires. Despite the public purpose being valid, the procedural invalidity due to mischaracterization of land type renders the acquisition proceedings without jurisdiction, warranting acceptance of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court's precedent in Somavanti establishes that the government's declaration under Section 6(1) that land is needed for public purpose is conclusive, subject only to challenge for colourable exercise of power. The appellant's argument that cement production for profit is not a public purpose faces a high bar, as the cement factory was in the public sector and served national interest (including the Rihand dam construction). The profit benefiting state revenues further supports the public purpose characterization. The procedural challenges regarding Section 17 urgency provisions and waste/arable land classification appear secondary to the main public purpose issue, which strongly favors the government's position under established precedent.

cases.graph_reasoning: The respondent's arguments align strongly with established precedents (Vajravelu, Bela Banerjee) requiring compensation principles to have rational nexus to actual value at acquisition time. The valuation methods—historical cost for unused machinery and written-down value per Income-tax Act for used machinery—appear arbitrary and disconnected from market value at acquisition, similar to the flawed anterior date valuation struck down in precedents. While the petitioner argues offsetting deficiencies across the undertaking as a whole, the Supreme Court precedents suggest each valuation principle must independently satisfy the 'just equivalent' test under Article 31(2), making the appeal likely to be rejected.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court found the Act violated Article 31 of the Constitution regarding compensation for acquisition. The Act prescribes a rigid formula for compensation based on written-down values and specific asset categories rather than market value of the undertaking as a going concern. Given the Supreme Court's historical scrutiny of compensation adequacy under Article 31 and the High Court's finding of constitutional invalidity, the appeal challenging this decision is likely to be rejected, upholding the High Court's view that the compensation mechanism is constitutionally deficient.

cases.graph_reasoning: The High Court invoked Section 95 IPC to exclude trivial harm, finding only a scratch on the elbow despite the appellant's claims of serious injury. The facts show the appellant exaggerated the incident (claiming bleeding incised wound and shoe throwing when only a scratch occurred from a file), declined medical examination, and the harm was objectively minimal. The petitioner's argument that Section 95 cannot apply to physical injury lacks merit as the provision explicitly covers 'harm' which includes trivial physical injuries. The High Court's factual finding that no person of ordinary sense would complain of such slight harm appears reasonable given the circumstances.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court found that the appellant grossly exaggerated the incident, the medical evidence was unreliable, and the injuries were trivial. The provocation by the appellant's husband and the finding that the harm was so slight that a person of ordinary sense would not complain strongly suggests the High Court would invoke Exception 1 to Section 323 IPC or find the case too trivial to warrant conviction. The appeal challenging the High Court's revisional order would likely be rejected as the High Court's findings are based on proper appreciation of evidence and legal principles regarding trivial harm.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellants have strong legal grounds based on established precedent that Article 181 of the Limitation Act applies only to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure, not to applications under Section 20 of the Arbitration Act. Multiple cited cases (Hansraj Gupta, Bai Manekbai, Sha Mulchand, Bombay Gas Company) consistently support this interpretation. The respondent's argument that Section 37(1) shows contrary intention appears weak, as that provision relates to arbitration proceedings before the arbitrator, not court applications for filing agreements. The limitation question regarding the underlying claim should be decided by the arbitrator, not at the threshold of the Section 20 application.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case centers on whether the application for filing an arbitration agreement is barred by limitation under Article 181 of the Limitation Act, 1908. There is a well-established catena of authorities, including Privy Council and Supreme Court decisions, holding that Article 181 applies only to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure. The appellants' application under Section 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, does not fall within this scope. The Judicial Commissioner's finding that the application was time-barred appears legally sound based on precedent, making rejection of the appeal likely.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central jurisdictional issue favors the appellant society. Section 48(1) of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act enumerates specific disputes that oust civil court jurisdiction, and a dispute between a registered society and a non-member, non-financing bank does not fall within clauses (a)-(e). The Explanation does not expand the scope to cover all non-member disputes. On merits, the trial court found the cheque was forged (defendant No.6's signature was forged), establishing the bank's prima facie liability for honoring a forged instrument without proper mandate. While the bank raises customer negligence as a defense, the forgery of a signature typically negates the mandate regardless of intervening negligence, and the trial court already found conspiracy and fraud by certain defendants. The legal framework and factual findings support the society's claim.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court dismissed the appeal on jurisdictional grounds under sections 48(1) and 57 of the Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, holding that civil courts lacked jurisdiction over disputes that should be referred to the Registrar. However, this jurisdictional objection was not raised in the written statements by defendants and appears to have been taken up only on appeal. The Supreme Court typically takes a strict view on such belated jurisdictional pleas, especially when the trial court has already adjudicated on merits and found fraud and conspiracy. Given that substantive findings favor the plaintiffs and the jurisdictional bar was raised belatedly, the appeal is likely to be accepted with the matter being remanded or the jurisdictional objection being overruled.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court precedents (Chugandas & Co.) establish that s.25(3) relief is available when tax was charged on the owner of the business under the 1918 Act, even if only remittances were taxed, and that business is not a separate unit of assessment. The facts show the assessee was taxed on remittances from foreign business under the 1918 Act, and rental income from properties owned by the foreign firm can be considered part of business income per Chugandas. The legal framework strongly supports the assessee's entitlement to relief under s.25(3) for both the foreign business and rental income upon discontinuance.
cases.raw_reasoning: The critical issue is whether foreign business income that was taxed only upon remittance to British India under the 1918 Act qualifies for relief under Section 25(3) of the 1922 Act. The High Court correctly held that Section 25(3) requires the business itself to have been 'charged' under the 1918 Act, not merely the remittances. Since only the receipts in India were taxed and not the foreign business operations themselves, the statutory prerequisite for relief is not satisfied. The appellant's claim lacks merit on this technical but decisive ground.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is statutory interpretation of Section 3(1)(c). The petitioners argue the provision is disjunctive ('or'), requiring either material alterations OR diminution of value for eviction. The respondent argues it should be read conjunctively ('and'), requiring both. The facts clearly establish: (1) tenant executed rent note prohibiting alterations, (2) tenant made alterations without consent in October 1954, and (3) the alterations involved structural changes (removal of partition wall, replacement of arch with iron girders). Applying ordinary rules of statutory construction, 'or' should be read disjunctively unless context requires otherwise. The cited precedents support that material alterations affecting form and structure of premises suffice for eviction, regardless of whether value was enhanced or diminished. The High Court's conjunctive reading appears to contradict plain statutory language.
cases.raw_reasoning: Both lower courts concurrently found that the tenant made material alterations without the landlord's consent, which constitutes a valid ground for eviction under Section 3(1)(c) of the U.P. Rent Control Act. The High Court's interpretation requiring both material alteration AND diminution of value appears erroneous as the provision is disjunctive ('or' not 'and'). The Supreme Court's analysis strongly supports the plain meaning interpretation favoring the landlords, making acceptance of the appeal highly probable.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant demonstrated valid business reasons for departing from the 'first come last go' rule by documenting specific skills and roles of retained employees (only accountant, only typist, specialized functions). The retrenchment was necessitated by a government ban making business impossible, statutory compensation under Section 25F was paid, and no mala fides were established. Precedents support management's discretion to retain employees with special skills or aptitude even when departing from seniority rules, provided valid reasons exist and the decision is bona fide.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant provided documented reasons for departing from the 'first come, last go' rule, demonstrating business necessity rather than mala fide intent. The Supreme Court's precedent recognizes that the seniority rule is not immutable and can be departed from for valid reasons. The Labour Court erred in declaring the entire retrenchment illegal merely due to departure from seniority, when the workmen themselves conceded that retrenchment was justified and the number of retained employees was appropriate.

cases.graph_reasoning: The case centers on whether Section 44B validly applies to resume this inam. The evidence strongly favors the respondent: (1) the Inam Fair Register officially recorded this as a service inam for temple archaka duties, (2) precedent establishes no presumption that kudiwaram was included in such grants to Brahmins, (3) the High Court already upheld Section 44B's validity and applicability to service inams, and (4) the petitioner's ultra vires arguments face the hurdle that religious endowments fell within provincial legislative competence. The petitioner's claim of personal inam contradicts the official record, and adverse possession appears insufficiently developed. The legal framework and factual record support resumption under Section 44B.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court found that the inams were personal and not liable to resumption under Section 44B, while also holding that the inam consisted only of melwaram. The Roman Catholic Mission's appeal challenges the melwaram-only finding, seeking recognition of both warams. However, given that the Mission has held the lands since 1894 through purchase from private parties, and the High Court already ruled in their favor on the crucial jurisdictional issue (personal inam not subject to resumption), the Supreme Court is likely to uphold the High Court's factual finding that only melwaram was granted, as this is supported by the historical evidence of the grant being limited to theerva (rent) rather than full proprietary rights.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner raises a strong procedural argument that Section 479A CrPC mandates a special procedure for witnesses giving false evidence, which bars the use of Section 476 CrPC when Section 479A applies. The facts show affidavits were sworn before an Oath Commissioner (not in court testimony), and the legal framework indicates that false affidavits fall under Sections 191/192 IPC, for which Section 479A(6) explicitly bars Section 476 proceedings. The failure to follow the mandatory Section 479A procedure appears to be a fatal procedural defect that would likely result in the appeal being accepted.
cases.raw_reasoning: The central legal issue is whether Section 479A bars prosecution under Section 199 IPC for false affidavits filed in court proceedings. The appellants argue that the procedural requirements of Section 479A were not followed, making the prosecution order invalid. Given that Section 479A was introduced specifically to regulate prosecutions for offenses in judicial proceedings and the High Court may have erred in distinguishing between testimony before the Registrar versus affidavits filed in court, there appears to be a substantial procedural question warranting appellate intervention. The absence of respondent representation further suggests potential merit in the appellant's technical legal argument.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court explicitly stated that both contentions of the petitioner (Mr. Patwardhan) are well-founded. The petitioner challenged the High Court's requirements for expert evidence and mandatory corroboration. The trial Magistrate's findings that the presumption under section 7 could not be raised due to lack of reasonable grounds, and that slips were not instruments of gaming, appear to have been improperly overturned by the High Court by imposing excessive evidentiary burdens. The Supreme Court's agreement with the petitioner's arguments strongly indicates the appeal will be accepted.
cases.raw_reasoning: The State's appeal challenges the High Court's requirement for expert corroboration and the corroboration of police inspector's evidence in gambling cases. The appellant's arguments appear legally sound - Section 3 of the Act broadly defines 'instruments of gaming' to include documents used as evidence of gaming, and the slips recording American futures bets would fall within this definition. The High Court's imposition of mandatory corroboration requirements appears to add conditions not explicitly required by the statute, which typically constitutes an error in law justifying appellate intervention.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether time taken to obtain certified copies should be excluded under s.12(2) of the Limitation Act when court rules don't mandate their annexation. The petitioners rely on Supreme Court precedents (Surty v. Chettyar, Haji Hassum) establishing that s.12(2) provides unqualified exclusion of time for obtaining copies regardless of whether rules require them. The respondents' argument that exclusion is conditional on mandatory annexation requirements conflicts with the plain language of s.12(2) and established jurisprudence. The Supreme Court has consistently held that the statutory provision for exclusion operates independently of procedural rules, making the petitioners' position legally stronger.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court's reasoning creates an illogical situation where filing early (without the order copy) bars the application, but filing later (with the order copy) or amending would have been within time due to Section 12(2) of the Limitation Act allowing exclusion of time for obtaining certified copies. This paradox suggests a legal error in the High Court's interpretation. The Supreme Court is likely to accept the appeal to correct this anomaly, as the petitioners acted diligently in seeking certified copies and the substantive merits (valuation tests and reversal) favored granting leave.

cases.graph_reasoning: The statutory interpretation strongly favors rejection. Section 5(1)(a) of the 1955 Act lacks explicit language extending protection to execution proceedings, unlike predecessor statutes (1917 and 1946/1949 Acts) which expressly covered pending executions. The successor judge correctly followed binding precedent (Suresh Chandra Datta) holding s. 5(1)(a) inapplicable to execution proceedings. The appellants' arguments rely on analogies to other rent control statutes, but the legislative history demonstrates deliberate omission of execution-stage protection in the 1955 Act. The decree predates the Act (1950 vs. 1955), and applying tenant protection retroactively to execution would require clear statutory language absent here.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants claim protection under Section 5 of the Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955, which came into force while execution proceedings were pending. The statutory language 'no tenant shall be ejected...except in execution of a decree' and the protective intent of tenancy legislation suggest the Act applies to pending executions, not just future suits. The initial trial court decision and supporting High Court precedent (Harsukh Saraqgi) favored this interpretation. While a later contrary precedent exists, the remedial nature of tenant protection statutes and the Act's comprehensive scheme protecting tenants from eviction support applying Section 5 to pending execution proceedings.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central legal issue is whether Section 9(1) of the Evacuee Interest (Separation) Act, 1951 operates retrospectively to reopen completed mortgage transactions and recharacterize past interest payments. The legal concepts strongly indicate that retrospectivity applies only to pending liabilities, not to reopening past accounts without explicit statutory language. The appellants had already obtained preliminary (1942) and final decrees (1945) before the 1951 Act, and Section 8(3) makes civil court decrees binding on the Competent Officer subject to Sections 9 and 10. The statute's non-obstante clause limits future liability on evacuee property to 5% simple interest but does not contain explicit language requiring reopening of past transactions. The respondent's argument for complete retrospective application from the mortgage date appears to exceed the statutory scope, making acceptance of the appeal likely.
cases.raw_reasoning: Section 9(1) of the Evacuee Interest (Separation) Act appears to mandate retrospective application limiting interest to 5% per annum simple, with the Act's Section 3 providing overriding effect notwithstanding any other law or instrument. The Appellate Officer's interpretation requiring fresh accounting from the mortgage date aligns with the statutory language giving the Act overriding effect. While the appellants have a decreed right, the special legislation's retrospective operation and the principle that excess interest should reduce principal appears to favor the Custodian's position, making rejection of the appeal more likely.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellants have a strong legal argument that Section 17 of the Jagirs Abolition Act mandates the Tribunal to decide appeals on merits even in the appellant's absence, making dismissal for non-prosecution ultra vires the statute. The applications for restoration were filed within the 30-day period under Regulation 21, demonstrating procedural compliance. The statutory scheme under Sections 17 and 20 requiring a final decision on merits appears to override the procedural regulations permitting dismissal for non-prosecution, creating a compelling case that the Tribunal exceeded its jurisdiction.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants present a strong statutory interpretation argument that Section 17(1) of the Jagirs Abolition Act mandates the Tribunal to 'decide the appeal and record its decision' on merits, not merely dispose of it procedurally. This interpretation is reinforced by Section 20 making Tribunal decisions final and conclusive, suggesting the legislature intended substantive adjudication. The Tribunal's dismissal for non-prosecution without deciding on merits appears ultra vires the mandatory statutory language, making the appellants' challenge legally meritorious.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue is whether the respondent's service was continuous enough to qualify for regularisation under Government Order GAD 46 SRR. The appellant claims a break in service on March 1, 1961, which would disqualify the respondent from regularisation and thus Article 311(2) protection. However, the High Court quashed the termination, suggesting it found the service continuous or the break inconsequential. Given that the respondent served continuously from March 1958 through July 1963 with only a one-day alleged break, and the regularisation order was designed to benefit local candidates with substantially continuous service, the technical one-day gap appears insufficient to defeat the regularisation claim. The appeal is likely to be rejected, upholding the High Court's decision.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court's interpretation that sub-clause (iv) requiring 'continuous service' only applies to breaks before December 31, 1959 appears strained and inconsistent with the plain language of the Government Order. The Order explicitly states services shall be regularised 'from the date of their appointment, from which their service is continuous' and that 'breaks in service will not be condoned even if such breaks are only for short periods.' The respondent had an admitted break on March 1, 1961 (between February 28 and March 2, 1961), which falls within the relevant period. The Government Order's clear requirement of continuous service from the initial appointment date through regularisation was not met, making the High Court's liberal interpretation legally vulnerable on appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The critical weakness is the respondent's argument that remuneration was paid for partnership services, not exclusively for HUF business. Section 10(2)(xv) requires expenditure to be 'wholly and exclusively' for the family business purpose. The agreement was made only between Babu Ram (Karta) and Gobardhandas, without clear evidence of consent from all competent family members or proper representation of minors' interests. The Jitmal Bhuramal precedent supports deductibility only when remuneration relates to family business, not partnership firms. These deficiencies in establishing a valid agreement and exclusive business purpose likely lead to rejection of the deduction claim.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court's prior precedent in Jitmal Bhuramal established that a Hindu undivided family can deduct salary paid to a member if justified by commercial expediency, without distinguishing between karta and junior members. The High Court's reliance on Hindu law commentaries suggesting a karta cannot receive remuneration appears overly rigid, as those sources acknowledge exceptions for 'special arrangements.' The appellant's case shows a documented agreement between adult members (karta and his brother) for Rs. 12,000 annual salary, consistently maintained over seven years. If this arrangement served legitimate business purposes and was agreed upon by competent family members, it should satisfy the commercial expediency test under Section 10(2)(xv), making the deduction permissible.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner faces significant procedural and substantive hurdles. Procedurally, the first question is conceded as a question of fact, not referable under section 66(2). The cited precedent Commissioner of Income-tax v. Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. establishes that only questions raised before or decided by the Tribunal can be referred, and new questions or aspects not previously raised are not referable. Substantively, the ITO found 'overwhelming proof' that the company neither purchased nor sold the shares, supporting a finding of deliberate fabrication. The penalty under section 28(1)(c) for concealment appears justified on the facts found. The petitioner's arguments about the meaning of 'income' and whether loss qualifies appear to raise new legal questions not properly before the Tribunal, making them non-referable under the established precedent.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Tribunal found deliberate fabrication of accounts with overwhelming evidence that the company neither purchased nor sold the shares as claimed. Multiple appellate authorities consistently upheld the penalty finding, with the Tribunal reducing it from Rs. 42,000 to Rs. 25,000 after review. The company's argument that the transaction being non-trading exempts it from penalty under section 28(1)(c) is weak, as the provision addresses fraudulent claims regardless of transaction nature. The consistent findings across three levels of tax authorities on fabrication of evidence strongly support rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The High Court's finding that the settlements constituted actual expenditure under Section 10(2)(xv) appears legally sound. The Bank made actual payments (Rs. 48,891 and Rs. 1,21,760) through bilateral settlements involving payment of differences between jewellery value and loan amounts, not mere forbearance. The expenditure was incurred for commercial expediency to maintain business goodwill and client confidence, which courts recognize as valid business purposes even absent strict legal liability. The precedent regarding currency notes supports deductibility of theft-related losses, and the petitioner's arguments focus on technical distinctions that may not overcome the commercial reality of actual payments made.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Bank's payments to constituents for stolen pledged jewellery appear to be business expenditure under Section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act. The settlements were made to maintain customer relationships and protect the Bank's reputation, which are legitimate business purposes. The High Court's finding that such payments constitute deductible business expenditure is likely to be upheld, as the amounts were actually paid out (not merely written off) and were incurred wholly and exclusively for business purposes - protecting the Bank's goodwill and continuing operations.

cases.graph_reasoning: The tax authorities had substantial evidence of suppressed turnover: unreliable books with missing vouchers, significantly lower profit margins (3.8%) compared to peers (6-7%), proven undisclosed sales through third parties, and unexplained cash credits where the creditor admitted inability to advance funds. The best judgment assessment estimating turnover at Rs. 12 lakhs with 6.5% profit rate appears reasonable and based on relevant materials. The Tribunal's factual findings, supported by these considerations, do not reveal any legal error warranting interference. The respondent's arguments lack merit as they cannot explain the discrepancies or provide evidence contradicting the authorities' conclusions.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court identified two substantial questions of law: whether the income estimation rested on irrelevant considerations and whether there was double taxation in adding both estimated business income and cash credits. The Tribunal's reliance on the assessee's admission about sales tax evasion (later not persisted with) and the potential double counting of secreted profits already included in the turnover estimation suggest procedural irregularities. Courts typically remand or modify assessments where estimation methods are questioned on legal grounds or where double taxation is alleged, particularly when the factual foundation for estimates appears questionable.

cases.graph_reasoning: Section 111 of the Indian Succession Act clearly states that the class of beneficiaries is determined at the testator's death unless possession is deferred. Here, the will gave an absolute bequest to grandsons with executors merely managing until majority - this is guardianship, not deferral of possession. The petitioner's argument that each grandson takes possession at majority does not constitute the type of deferral contemplated by Section 111. The plain terms of the will, combined with the statutory rule, strongly favor limiting the class to grandsons alive at Chockalingam's death (February 7, 1943), excluding Chockalingam born in August 1946.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court correctly applied Section 111 of the Indian Succession Act, which provides that when a bequest is made to a class of persons, the class is ascertained at the testator's death unless a contrary intention appears. The will shows no express provision deferring the vesting or distribution beyond the testator's death. At Chockalingam's death on February 7, 1943, only Narayanan and Viswanathan existed as grandsons, so they alone would take the estate in equal shares. The subsequent birth of two more grandsons does not alter this determination, as the class closed at the testator's death.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central issue concerns whether Roman numeral 'I' satisfies Rule 73(2)'s requirement for marking '1' as first preference. The legal framework explicitly states that 'figure 1 may be in international form, Roman form, or Indian language form' - this directly supports the respondent's position that Roman 'I' is valid. The petitioner's narrow textual interpretation requiring exclusively Arabic numerals contradicts the rule's express allowance for multiple forms. The procedural objection regarding the decree appears weak given Section 98 specifies an 'order' rather than decree is required. The margin of 47 votes suggests the election result is unlikely to be overturned on this interpretation.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court's interpretation that Roman numeral 'I' should be treated as equivalent to Arabic numeral '1' for expressing first preference appears reasonable, as it reflects the voter's clear intent and the substance-over-form principle in election law. The procedural objection regarding the decree copy was already rejected by the High Court based on statutory provisions. With 460 of the 491 disputed votes being validated, Satya Ketu retained a winning margin of 16 votes, making the appellant's challenge unlikely to succeed on either procedural or substantive grounds.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioners have a strong case on procedural grounds. The respondents failed to comply with mandatory requirements under Chapter VIII of CrPC, specifically Section 112, which requires a written order setting out the substance of information and bond details before any further action including detention. The cited precedent Sharon Kumar Gupta supports this strict procedural requirement. The arrests under Section 151 also appear questionable as they require actual knowledge of design to commit cognizable offence, not mere apprehension. The procedural violations are fundamental and go to the root of lawful detention authority.
cases.raw_reasoning: The court finds multiple fundamental legal violations: (1) arrests under Section 151 were unlawful as they required knowledge of design to commit a cognizable offence, not mere apprehension of breach of peace under Section 107; (2) the distinction between 'apprehension' and 'knowledge' was not satisfied; (3) petitioners were allegedly not informed of reasons for arrest nor produced before magistrates as required; (4) the magistrates' conduct in providing affidavits to prosecution counsel raises serious concerns about impartiality. These procedural and substantive violations of fundamental rights under Article 22 strongly indicate the petitions will be accepted and habeas corpus relief granted.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's argument that fresh permission is required under the amended s.19 faces a strong legal obstacle: the well-established doctrine that amending acts do not retrospectively affect pending proceedings unless expressly stated. The execution proceeding commenced on July 22, 1964, before the December 21, 1964 amendment, and the March 23, 1965 application is merely a continuation. Applying the new permission requirement to already-commenced proceedings would give the amendment retrospective effect, which courts typically avoid. The facts show permission was already obtained on June 19, 1964 under the original s.19, and requiring fresh permission would create absurdity regarding limitation periods for execution applications.
cases.raw_reasoning: The respondents obtained both the eviction decree (December 5, 1960) and the required permission under Section 19 (June 19, 1964) before the 1964 Amendment came into force on December 21, 1964. The execution application was filed around July 22, 1964, also before the amendment. Since all procedural requirements under the original Section 19 were satisfied before the amendment, the respondents had vested rights to execute the decree. The amendment's retrospective application to already-granted permissions would likely be viewed as arbitrary and violative of established legal rights, making acceptance of the appeal probable.

cases.graph_reasoning: While the petitioner raises procedural concerns about ex parte condonation of delay, the primary constitutional challenge to Section 26's proviso appears weak. The statute provides sufficient guidance through the context of 'major misconduct' in industrial law, and Rule 20(1) demonstrates reasonable exercise of delegated power by specifying 11 categories of misconduct. The excessive delegation argument likely fails as the legislature provided adequate policy guidance. The procedural irregularity in delay condonation, though problematic, may not be sufficient to overturn the substantive validity of the provision or grant relief to the appellant.
cases.raw_reasoning: The challenge is based on excessive delegation regarding the proviso to Section 26(1) which allows the State Government to prescribe what constitutes misconduct. Indian courts have consistently upheld similar provisions where the legislature sets the policy and delegates only the details of implementation to the executive. The proviso provides sufficient guidance by limiting it to 'misconduct' supported by 'satisfactory evidence' after an 'inquiry', making the delegation valid. The procedural irregularity regarding condonation of delay was subsequently cured by a hearing on April 4, 1961, weakening the appellant's case further.

cases.graph_reasoning: Under Order XXXIV Rule 8 CPC, a mortgagor can deposit amounts due before the final decree is passed to secure redemption rights, even if after the time fixed under Rule 7. The appellant deposited Rs. 42,204/5/- before the final decree, which appears to cover the principal and interest adjudged in the preliminary decree. The critical issue is whether the extra 6% interest (9% vs 3%) undertaken during the stay period must be included in this deposit. The undertaking for extra interest was a separate arrangement for obtaining stay, not part of the decreed amount under Rule 7(c), and could be enforced separately. The appellant's substantial compliance with the decree amount before final decree likely preserves the redemption right, though the shortage issue creates some uncertainty.
cases.raw_reasoning: The deposit was made nearly 5 years after the stipulated deadline. While a stay was granted, it only suspended immediate compliance, not indefinitely extended the time limit. Mortgage redemption laws require strict adherence to timelines, and such substantial delay would likely result in foreclosure rights for the mortgagee.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court's own finding that Jugal Kishore 'defied orders on pretext of illness and abused process' is critical. However, the absence of any finding that the appellant company was responsible for or colluded in this non-appearance creates a fundamental problem with holding the company liable by striking its defence. The doctrine of separate legal personality between company and directors, combined with the lack of express penalty provisions in Order XXIX Rule 3 and the limitations on Section 151 inherent powers when express Code provisions exist, strongly suggests the striking off of defence was improper. The petitioner's argument that the Legislature intentionally provided no penalty for director non-appearance appears legally sound.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court's precedents establish that inherent powers under Section 151 cannot override express Code provisions or be exercised where the Code exhaustively covers a topic. Order XXIX Rule 3 specifically governs examination of company directors, and the Court appears to be examining whether striking off defense exceeded this framework. The appellant's argument that Section 151 was improperly invoked to circumvent express procedural limitations has strong doctrinal support from the cited precedents (Padam Sen, Manohar Lal Chopra, Arjun Singh), suggesting the High Court's order may be set aside for exceeding jurisdictional bounds.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts establish a premeditated conspiracy to commit burglary where the accused deliberately prepared instruments of restraint and chloroform, decoyed the victim to a lonely place, and systematically sealed his mouth, tied it, and plugged his nostrils with chloroform-soaked cotton. Applying the Virsa Singh test for Section 300 thirdly, the bodily injury inflicted (complete obstruction of breathing passages) was objectively sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, and the deliberate, preplanned nature of these specific acts demonstrates intention to inflict that injury. The common intention under Section 34 is clearly established through the conspiracy and coordinated execution. The petitioners' arguments that they intended only to render the victim unconscious are undermined by the objective lethality of simultaneously blocking all breathing passages, making the murder conviction legally sound.
cases.raw_reasoning: The facts establish a clear case of murder under Section 302 IPC. The accused completely sealed the victim's mouth with adhesive plaster and handkerchief, and plugged his nostrils with chloroform-soaked cotton, making breathing impossible and causing death by asphyxiation. Such actions demonstrate knowledge that death was the likely consequence, satisfying the mens rea for murder. The appellants' argument that they only intended to render the victim unconscious is contradicted by the deliberate and complete obstruction of all breathing passages. The confession's claim of intent to merely incapacitate cannot override the objective evidence of actions that would inevitably cause death.

cases.graph_reasoning: The trial court found no severance of joint status between Bijendra Narain and Bidya Narain despite the 1923 decree, which merely specified shares without evidencing unequivocal intention to separate. The panchas meeting admission by Bidya Narain and sons that properties were joint family properties strongly supports Bijendra's claim. Section 66 CPC does not bar claims that auction properties were acquired with joint family funds (distinguished from benami claims). The legal framework under Mitakshara law presumes jointness until clear severance is proved, and mere share specification without separation of possession or unequivocal conduct is insufficient. The respondents' evidence of separation appears weak against the admission and legal presumptions favoring the appellant.
cases.raw_reasoning: The trial court found no severance of joint family status by the 1923 decree and held properties remained joint, entitling Bijendra Narain to partition. The key legal issue is whether the 1923 consent decree effected a complete partition or merely defined shares without severing status. Given that the decree explicitly stated 'the family estate is still joint' and only provided for future partition by metes and bounds, the trial court's interpretation appears legally sound. The defendants' argument of tenancy-in-common lacks strong support when the decree language preserved joint family character. The appeal challenging this finding faces significant legal hurdles.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts strongly indicate directors received substantial additional remuneration (Rs. 1,11,000) without rendering any extra services, while managing agents performed most work. Under section 10(2)(xv), deduction requires expenditure 'wholly and exclusively for business purposes.' The cited precedent Jethabhai Hirji supports disallowing payments not genuinely for business purposes. Despite the valid special resolution, income-tax authorities can scrutinize whether payment truly serves business needs beyond mere legal obligation. The absence of additional services and historical low fees (Rs. 100/month) suggest this was not a genuine business expenditure.
cases.raw_reasoning: The key issue is whether the additional remuneration of Rs. 1,11,090 paid to directors qualifies as expenditure 'wholly and exclusively' for business purposes under Section 10(2)(xv). The facts show that two directors were already nominees of managing agents who received substantial remuneration (Rs. 11,70,899), and no extra services were rendered by directors to justify the additional payment. The Income-tax Officer, Appellate Tribunal, and High Court all found against the assessee. While the payment was legally valid between the company and directors, tax deductibility requires the expenditure to be genuinely incurred for business purposes, not merely authorized by shareholders. The absence of additional services and the timing of the resolution suggest this was profit distribution rather than business expenditure.

cases.graph_reasoning: The core issue is whether the Assistant Secretary had authority to terminate pre-existing teachers. Section 34(2) specifically protects pre-existing teachers taken over by the State Board with protected emoluments and seniority, which appears to be a specific provision that would prevail over the general deeming provision in s.55(2). Additionally, the principle from Bachittar Singh requiring actual communication of termination orders to affected individuals strengthens the respondents' position, as the resolution of November 20, 1962 appears to be a policy directive rather than individualized termination orders. The statutory interpretation favoring specific protective provisions over general ones, combined with the procedural defect in communication, suggests the appeal challenging the terminations will likely be accepted.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves interpretation of transitional provisions under Section 55(2) of the Assam Elementary Education Act, 1962, particularly regarding the status and continuation of authorities and appointments made under the repealed 1954 Act. The saving clause's language 'shall be deemed to be constituted or made under this Act, and continue to function' suggests legislative intent to preserve existing arrangements until new actions are taken. The structural shift from School Boards to a centralized State Board system, combined with Section 34(2)'s protection of employees' emoluments and seniority, indicates the legislature intended continuity of service. Courts typically interpret such transitional provisions liberally to protect vested rights and prevent disruption, which favors the respondents' position.

cases.graph_reasoning: The compensation paid for breach of contracts to purchase textile machinery constitutes capital expenditure, not revenue expenditure. The machinery would have been a capital asset, and the payment to avoid acquiring this capital asset retains its capital character under section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which explicitly excludes capital expenditure from deductible business expenses. The cited precedent and the nature of the transaction strongly support disallowance of the deduction.
cases.raw_reasoning: The compensation paid for cancellation of contracts to purchase capital assets (machinery) is typically treated as capital expenditure, not revenue expenditure. The Supreme Court has consistently held that payments arising from cancellation of contracts for acquiring capital assets are capital in nature and not deductible under section 10(2)(xv). The fact that all three lower authorities (Income-tax Officer, Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and Tribunal) unanimously rejected the claim strengthens the likelihood of dismissal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant fails to satisfy the statutory definition of kuzhikanam under s.2(28) of the Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1964, which requires transfer of fruit-bearing trees standing on the land at the time of transfer. The 1921 deed expressly reserved these trees for the plaintiff, transferring only the right to plant new trees. The appellant also fails to establish kudiyiruppu status under s.2(26) as there is no evidence of a residential building. Without qualifying as a tenant under either s.2(57)(d) or s.2(57)(h), the appellant cannot claim protection under s.13. The statutory definitions are exhaustive and override customary understandings.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's claim rests on being classified as either a kuzhikanamdar or kudiyiruppu holder under the Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1963. However, the original 1921 deed was explicitly for a fixed 12-year term with express provisions for surrender of possession upon payment.
